10002.title: Stop Food Waste & Feed the Hungry in Lower East Side 10:40PM-11:10PM!

10002.description: Help your community to stop food waste and fight hunger by bringing excess food to homeless shelters. You will be taking bags of excess food, which would have been thrown out by the restaurant, to the nearest homeless shelter. This is a great opportunity to gain community service experience while helping others at the same time!!!! Please sign up for events directly on our website: http://www.rescuingleftovercuisine.org/calendar
10002.title: Stop Food Waste & Feed The Hungry!!

10002.description: Global Potential (GP) is a non-profit organization founded in 2007. GP provides urban youth from low-income communities with an 16 month leadership program, giving them the skills and perspective to effect positive change in their lives and communities. Youth engage in leadership training, social entrepreneurship, international cultural exchange and service learning. GP's vision is that as youth develop, communities develop. Global Potential is looking for a Salesforce Database Manager manage a team of salesforce database coordinators, perform file maintenance, data hygiene, and quality control. This position provides assistance in maintaining data integrity, provide leadership and improve Salesforce processes. The ideal candidate has a proven ability to maintain databases, willing to learn, demonstrates strong attention to details, understands the importance of clean data, and has excellent time management skills. This position requires the candidate to work onsite(in the office), preferably during office hours. Responsibilities: - Manage the company's Salesforce database - Regularly perform database de-duping and cleanup procedures - Be a Salesforce subject matter expert for the organization and manage a team of salesforce database coordinators - Identify improvement opportunities to optimize system processes - Create and maintain training documentation and perform user training - Transfer past data into salesforce Qualifications/Skill Requirements: Ability to be detail-oriented and highly organized Leadership skills Proficient in data manipulation and experience working with large data sets required Hands-on experience with Salesforce or another database is a plus Salesforce Administrator Certification and/or Trailhead badges are a big plus but not mandatory. GP can provide training if applicant has other database experience Trailhead is a prerequisite. This tutorial can be incorporated into a candidate's orientation if they haven't completed the online tutorial upon joining the organization. Takes Initiative and interest in problem solving Steadfast commitment to collaboration and teamwork
10002.title: Salesforce Database Manager

10002.description: Global Potential is looking for a Salesforce Database Coordinator to perform file maintenance, data hygiene, and quality control. This position provides assistance in maintaining data integrity, training users and improving Salesforce processes. The ideal candidate has a proven ability to maintain databases, willing to learn, demonstrates strong attention to details, understands the importance of clean data, and has excellent time management skills. This position requires the candidate to work onsite(in the office), preferably during office hours. Responsibilities: - Manage the company's Salesforce database - Regularly perform database de-duping and cleanup procedures - Be a Salesforce subject matter expert for the organization and provide staff with basic support - Identify improvement opportunities to optimize system processes - Create and maintain training documentation and perform user training - Transfer past data into salesforce Qualifications/Skill Requirements: − Ability to be detail-oriented and highly organized - Proficient in data manipulation and experience working with large data sets required - Hands-on experience with Salesforce or another database is a plus - Trailhead is a prerequisite for this position. This online tutorial will be incorporated into a candidate's orientation for those who do not have the trailhead badge. Salesforce Administrator Certification is also a big plus but not mandatory. GP can provide training if applicant has other database experience. - Takes Initiative and interest in problem solving - Steadfast commitment to collaboration and teamwork
10002.title: Salesforce Database Coordinator

10002.description: Global Potential's mission is to empower youth and communities around the world to energize each other through education, international service learning, social entrepreneurship and cultural exchange. Each year, Global Potential trains 500 youth aged between 15 to 23. These youth have high potential and self-vision to become leaders, change makers and social entrepreneurs in their urban and rural low-income communities around the world. Most GP participants are first generation immigrant youth and originate from dozens of countries. Global Potential's holistic model positively transforms the lives of urban youth.They shape the future and become leaders and entrepreneurs in business, community development, education and politics. For more information please visit www.global-potential.org The College and Career Access Coordinator will be responsible for facilitating college and career readiness workshops with GP youth (high school juniors and seniors), compiling opportunities for youth in transition (scholarships, gap year programs, internships), and coordinating youth's participation in college and career events. Responsibilities include: Engage with GP Alumni to support them in their role as peer mentors Compile resources for postsecondary opportunities, including college applications, scholarships, internships, and gap year programs Provide coaching in writing resumes and personal statements Assist the Program Manager in preparing deliverables to the program funder Gather and maintain data in our Salesforce database system Coordinate college and career events with GP partner organization and high schools, including Q & A panels with GP Alumni Collaborate with Program Coordinators to plan and facilitate GP workshops Experience with serving undocumented youth in preparation for college (i.e. access to scholarships, outsourcing to organizations like the Door for applying for residency, having a roster of translators-specifically for our African youth). Requirements for this position: Experience in compiling college and career opportunities for high school youth Minimum of 3 months, preferably 6 months commitment. Minimum of 10-15 hours per week Available to work in the office at least one day/week Flexible to work offsite at GP's partner high schools Experience with Salesforce or any other database management system is not required but preferred; GP will provide training No language requirements; Spanish, Haitian Creole, or French preferred Currently attending College in New York City; College Degree in any discipline preferred. This is a pilot program so there is an opportunity to bring one's own creativity and ideas to further develop the program. This position reports to and works collaboratively with the Program Manager. We are looking for an immediate start. If interested in this role, please send your resume to hr@global-potential.org indicating the title, ' College and Career Access Coordinator', in the subject line.
10002.title: College and Career Readiness Coordinator

10003.description: Join members of our Junior Board and the young men of the Kaplan House for a night of sports and games.
10003.title: Young Professionals: Recreational Night at Kaplan House (Manhattan)
10003.org: Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services

10003.description: Calling all science enthusiasts! The World Science Festival is back! The annual live, week-long New York Festival, which launched in 2008, has collectively drawn more than a million and a half visitors, with millions more viewing the programs online. Volunteers are the heart and soul of the World Science Festival, serving as our ambassadors to the public and participants alike. They are a welcoming face to visitors, chock-full of information about the Festival and its programs. Volunteers also support the many production teams that make so many compelling programs and experiences possible. Qualifications: · Feel comfortable working with people of all backgrounds, ages, and levels of familiarity with science. · Possess excellent communication skills. · Have a background in science, or a passion for learning and sharing knowledge. · Be dedicated, committed, reliable, flexible and professional. · Be at least 16 years old. The 2017 World Science Festival runs from May 30 - June 4, 2017. You can volunteer for one day or for all of them! We also need volunteer help for the two weeks leading up to the Festival. What’s Involved? · A quick & easy application process · A mandatory volunteer orientation on May 23, 2017 · A post-event wrap party To apply, visit our website at worldsciencefestival.com.
10003.title: World Science Festival 2017 / Call for Volunteers

10003.description: Mount Sinai Beth Israel, located in Manhattan’s Lower East Side- Gramercy Park- neighborhood, seeks volunteers with an interest in counseling, public health, social work, or pastoral care. In order to ensure that we provide high quality care, Mount Sinai Beth Israel has created a Chi Cart program for staff. Volunteers visit clinical and administrative floors in the hospital and provide a space for our employees to spiritually and physically recharge. Volunteers will be given resources to serve tea, snacks, and aromatherapy as a way to help staff take a break. Volunteers will have the opportunity to go behind the scenes of the hospital, participate in reporting data from each visit, and gain experience in conducting informal group counseling sessions. Volunteers must be comfortable with introducing themselves to the floor and encouraging staff members to take a short break with them. In addition to being warm and welcoming, volunteers should be comfortable with hospital systems and vernacular. Qualifications: Students: Mature, caring students. Ideal for students interested in pursuing social work or counseling. Must have completed 2 college level courses in a relevant field. Must be 18+. Community Members: Mature, caring, and compassionate people who would like to engage in supporting the well-being of professionals at a local hospital. Must have 1-2 years of experience working in a relevant setting.
10003.title: Chi Cart Program

10003.description: GO Project: Who We Are and What We Do The GO Project shapes the futures of low-income New York City public school children by providing critical academic, social, and emotional support starting in the early elementary years. GO provides year-round educational and family support services to children who are performing below grade level and equips them with the confidence and skills needed to succeed at school, at home, and in life. GO Getter Summer Internship: How YOU Can Help The GO Project summer internship is an opportunity for high school students to learn and develop leadership skills while working with GO Project students in academic and/or enrichment classes. During the 5-week GO Summer program, interns will be supporting instruction in one of our K -7 th grade classrooms under the guidance of a Head Teacher or Enrichment Teacher. Interns will work in small groups or one-to-one within the classroom to help students complete projects, remain focused, and build confidence as learners. Morning interns provide support in an academic classroom setting for math and literacy. Afternoon interns provide support in a particular enrichment activity, such as: art, theater, ballet, hip-hop, capoeira, yoga, and more. Interns will also be participating in rigorous daily professional development sessions where Echoing Green’s book, Work on Purpose, will be used to help them discover and enhance their passions (HEART) and their talents (HEAD) to become change-making leaders in their community (HUSTLE). A strong social justice-centered curriculum and required readings will form the core framework for the internship. At the end of the summer, interns will have completed a portfolio with work from daily classroom and professional development sessions, co-led a professional development session, gained leadership skills, and developed a culminating Hustle project that they will showcase for other GO Project interns, staff members, board members, and community supporters. Time Commitment ¨ Attend mandatory orientation and trainings June 28 th-June 30 th, 2017 ¨ Commitment to the entire summer session is required. July 5 th-August 4 th, 2017, Monday-Friday, either the morning academic session (8:30am-2pm) or the afternoon enrichment session (12pm-5:30pm). Daily participation in professional development sessions. Location ¨ Avenues; The World School (259 Tenth Avenue, New York, NY 10001); or ¨ Grace Church School (86 Fourth Avenue, New York, NY 10003); or ¨ Grace Church High School (46 Cooper Square, New York, NY 10003) Location and internship schedule will be assigned upon hire. Responsibilities ¨ Assist teachers and work one-to-one or in small groups with students who are in need of academic intervention. ¨ Actively engage with the students, teachers, fellow interns, and other program staff. ¨ Enthusiastically participate in daily professional development sessions. ¨ Attend all sessions punctually and consistently. ¨ Co-lead one professional development session during the summer. ¨ Contribute regularly to the volunteer blog. ¨ Read all assigned materials. ¨ Meet all internship deadlines. Benefits ¨ Personal gratification through enhancing the lives of young learners. ¨ Development of leadership skills. ¨ Ongoing personal and professional development opportunities. ¨ Continual onsite support from GO Project staff. ¨ Portfolio for support with college and career selection. ¨ Completion of a service learning project which will have a larger impact on the community. ¨ Potential participation on the High School Student Leadership Council. Qualifications ¨ High school students in good academic standing (rising 10 th to recent high school grads). ¨ Commitment to and belief in all children’s ability to succeed and thrive. ¨ Commitment to social justice through educational equity. ¨ Ability to work collaboratively on a team. ¨ Strong or emerging leadership skills. ¨ Punctuality and professionalism. Application Process ¨ Complete online application form. ¨ Submit a personal statement explaining why you want to intern with the GO Project and reflecting on a social justice issue which you consider the most important (Maximum 750 words). ¨ Submit a copy of your most recent school transcript. ¨ Provide one written letter of recommendation a ( References can only be teachers, employers, school administrators, supervisors). ¨ Attend an interview as part of the initial screening process. The online internship application can be accessed on the GO Project website under Get Involved, Volunteer Opportunities, GO Getter Summer Internship www.goprojectnyc.org. If you have any questions about the internship, please contact Emily Ong, Community Engagement Program Manager, at eong@goprojectnyc.org. Deadline for application submission will be Monday, May 15 th, 2017. Early applications are encouraged as space is limited.
10003.title: GO Getter High School Summer Internship

Qualifications ¨ High school students in good academic standing (rising 10 th to recent high school grads). ¨ Commitment to and belief in all children’s ability to succeed and thrive. ¨ Commitment to social justice through educational equity. ¨ Ability to work collaboratively on a team. ¨ Strong or emerging leadership skills. ¨ Punctuality and professionalism. Application Process ¨ Complete online application form. ¨ Submit a personal statement explaining why you want to intern with the GO Project and reflecting on a social justice issue which you consider the most important. ¨ Submit a copy of your most recent school transcript. ¨ Provide one written letter of recommendation a ( References can only be teachers, employers, school administrators, supervisors). ¨ Attend an interview as part of the initial screening process. The online internship application can be accessed on the GO Project website under Get Involved, Volunteer Opportunities, GO Getter Summer Internship www.goprojectnyc.org. If you have any questions about the internship, please contact Emily Ong, Community Engagement Program Manager, at eong@goprojectnyc.org. Deadline for application submission will be Monday, May 15 th, 2017. Early applications are encouraged as space is limited.
10003.title: GO Getter High School Summer Internship

10003.description: HEART + HEAD = HUSTLE The GO Project shapes the futures of low-income New York City public school children by providing critical academic, social, and emotional support starting in the early elementary years. GO provides year-round educational and family support services to children who are performing below grade level and equips them with the confidence and skills needed to succeed at school, at home, and in life. Internship Description The GO Project summer internship is an opportunity for high school students to learn and develop leadership skills while working with GO Project students in academic and/or enrichment classes. During the 5-week GO Summer program, interns will be supporting instruction in one of our K -7 th grade classrooms under the guidance of a Head Teacher or Enrichment Teacher. Interns will work in small groups or one-to-one within the classroom to help students complete projects, remain focused, and build confidence as learners. Morning interns provide support in an academic classroom setting for math and literacy. Afternoon interns provide support in a particular enrichment activity, such as: art, theater, ballet, hip-hop, capoeira, yoga, and more. Interns will also be participating in rigorous daily professional development sessions where Echoing Green’s book, Work on Purpose, will be used to help them discover and enhance their passions (HEART) and their talents (HEAD) to become change-making leaders in their community (HUSTLE). A strong social justice-centered curriculum and required readings will form the core framework for the internship. At the end of the summer, interns will have completed a portfolio with work from daily classroom and professional development sessions, co-led a professional development session, gained leadership skills, and developed a culminating Hustle project that they will showcase for other GO Project interns, staff members, board members, and community supporters. Time Commitment ¨ Attend mandatory orientation and trainings June 28 th-June 30 th, 2017 ¨ Commitment to the entire summer session is required. ¨ July 5 th-August 4 th, 2017, Monday-Friday, either the morning academic session (8:30am-2pm) or the afternoon enrichment session (12pm-5:30pm). ¨ Daily participation in professional development sessions. Location ¨ Avenues; The World School (259 Tenth Avenue, New York, NY 10001); or ¨ Grace Church School (86 Fourth Avenue, New York, NY 10003); or ¨ Grace Church High School (46 Cooper Square, New York, NY 10003) Location and internship schedule will be assigned upon hire. Responsibilities ¨ Assist teachers and work one-to-one or in small groups with students who are in need of academic intervention. ¨ Actively engage with the students, teachers, fellow interns, and other program staff. ¨ Enthusiastically participate in daily professional development sessions. ¨ Attend all sessions punctually and consistently. ¨ Co-lead one professional development session during the summer. ¨ Contribute regularly to the volunteer blog. ¨ Read all assigned materials. ¨ Meet all internship deadlines. Benefits ¨ Personal gratification through enhancing the lives of young learners. ¨ Development of leadership skills. ¨ Ongoing personal and professional development opportunities. ¨ Continual onsite support from GO Project staff. ¨ Portfolio for support with college and career selection. ¨ Completion of a service learning project which will have a larger impact on the community. ¨ Potential participation on the High School Student Leadership Council. Qualifications ¨ High school students in good academic standing (rising 10 th to recent high school grads). ¨ Commitment to and belief in all children’s ability to succeed and thrive. ¨ Commitment to social justice through educational equity. ¨ Ability to work collaboratively on a team. ¨ Strong or emerging leadership skills. ¨ Punctuality and professionalism.

10003.description: The Kids Creative Board of Directors is seeking new members! We are looking for a diverse group of individuals who are passionate about our mission of developing confident, community-minded youth through arts education programs in NYC. Everyone is invited to apply! Board members support and guide the organization and serve on a variety of fun committees, including Board Development, Fundraising, and Finance! Board members are responsible for: * Financial oversight * Ensuring adherence to governing regulations * Programmatic oversight and evaluation * Strategy and planning We are looking for new members from all sectors and backgrounds with a variety of skills that can help Kids Creative continue to develop confident youth. If you are passionate about children or the arts, we want to hear from you!
10003.title: Come join the Kids Creative Board of Directors!

10003.description: Help change the world! #HelpMeImagine a world that is safe and supportive of all people, regardless of their identity. Lend your time and talents to provide our young people that future. Volunteer Position: Front Desk Location: HMI Purpose: Hetrick-Martin Institute is looking for an individual who can volunteer to provide support at the front desk. Expectations/Responsibilities of the Position: Greet visitors, students, staff Have visitors sign in Answer phone Qualifications: Able to commit to one shifts: Monday, Wednesday, OR Friday: 9 - 12 pm Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday: 12 - 3:30 pm Please send apply online at www.hmi.org
10003.title: Front Desk Assistant

10003.description: Kaplan House is an urban residential facility for 25 older adolescent males, ages 17 to 21. The facility provides an extensive independent living skills program and therapeutic and support services. As a Math Tutor, you will have the opportunity to share your knowledge and make a difference with residents of Kaplan House by tutoring high school and/or college level math. You will work in either one-on-one or group tutoring sessions.
10003.title: Math Tutor - Manhattan
10003.org: Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services

10003.description: We just received our tax exemption and will be holding our first fundraiser at Drama Book Shop on W. 40th St in Manhattan. We need inspiring public speakers who jive with our mission statement (www.BreakDiving.org) and who have a motivational or inspiring story to tell the audience. The best stories will probably be underdog stories, stories of great success (at whatever level), stories of perseverence, or something uniquely educational. Bottom line: if the audience leaves smarter, happier, more confident, or touched in some small way, that's the type of story we're looking for. While the position is voluntary, we will be using your name in publicity for the event, and also at the event too. So this could be a way to broaden the reach of your name, or brand, even in just a small way. If interested, please, don't hesitate to reach out! We'd love to hear from you.
10003.title: Seeking Public Speakers in NYC Area For Our Very First Fundraiser

10003.description: We need a volunteer manager for a \"hunger run\". A hunger run would be arranging an event, publicizing an event, bringing groups of people together, making healthy meals and delivering the meals. We engaged groups of people from all backgrounds to come together to make the healthy meals and deliver it to where the hungry are. We want to recruit volunteer groups, donors and event managers. We work in several cities (Washington DC, New York, Boston,Chicago and Dallas) We need help to organize and market the program, recruit groups, raise funds and purshase the food ingrediants.
10003.title: Volunteer need to help organize a hunger van event in New York City

10003.description: Volunteer Certified Long Term Care Ombudsmen are a vital link between residents of long term care facilities and the government resources able to investigate and resolve their problems. Ombudsmen are committed to advocating for these senior citizens and ensuring that residents' rights, unmet needs and complaints are handled and resolved effectively, while maintaining resident and complainant confidentiality. In this way, Ombudsmen protect and help improve the quality of life for the frailest of New York's senior population. Being an Ombudsman is an important responsibility that is taken on with great care and professionalism. In New York State, Ombudsmen are certified only after receiving extensive training. As Ombudsmen take on their duties in assigned facilities, they are supported by a network of fellow Ombudsmen, Coordinators, and the State Office. If you are interested in becoming an ombudsman please contact Mary Jane Wolper mwolper@cidny.org
10003.title: What is a Certified Long Term Care Ombudsman?
10003.org: CIDNY- Long Term Care Ombudsman Program

10003.description: The Kaplan Center for Community Services helps people who are struggling with a range of emotional and social problems. The Kaplan Center also provides psychiatric and social services to Jewish emigres from the former Soviet Union and elsewhere, and counseling services for senior citizens and their families. As a Client Companion for the Kaplan Center, you will assist one of the clients using their mental health services. This client lives independently in Boro Park, is in his mid to late 50s, and is looking for someone to accompany him to the grocery store as well as expose him to exercise, which can be as simple as going for a walk around the neighborhood. This opportunity is available Monday Friday in Boro Park. Volunteer is needed 1x/week in the afternoon for at least 6 months.
10003.title: Client Companion- Brooklyn (Boro Park)
10003.org: Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services

10003.description: Help your community to stop food waste and fight hunger by bringing excess food to homeless shelters. You will be taking bags of excess food, which would have been thrown out by the restaurant, to the nearest homeless shelter. This is a great opportunity to gain community service experience while helping others at the same time!!!! Please sign up for events directly on our website: http://www.rescuingleftovercuisine.org/calendar
10003.title: Volunteers Needed To Help Fight Food Waste & Feed The Hungry!

10003.description: Samaritans of New York operates the city’s 24-hour suicide prevention hotline. Last year, we answered over 82,000 hotline calls. Samaritans is part of a well-established international network of 400 centers in 42 countries where over 20,000 volunteers provide crisis response and emotional support services to people who are in distress, depressed and suicidal. Samaritans is currently accepting applicants for the March Hotline Training Class. If you are interested in becoming a Samaritans volunteer, please contact us to attend one of the following orientations: Tuesday, May 9 Wednesday, May 17 Thursday, May 25 To receive a Volunteer Information packet, please email samaritansnycvol@aol.com with the following information: -your full name -phone number -residential street address Or: - Inquire through our website: http://samaritansnyc.org/volunteer-2/ - Call 212-673-3041 to receive a Volunteer Information Packet by mail We look forward to hearing from you! Volunteer requirements: Must be at least 21 Good English speaking + written skills Willing to work as part of a collaborative team Available to donate: 1 weekday morning, afternoon, evening or weekend shift a week 1 overnight shift a month No experience necessary!

Samaritans is currently accepting applicants for the March Hotline Training Class. 10003.description: Have Fun Running a Cafe Cart and Interacting with Students and Older Adults! Opportunity: Volunteer Program: Work with a multi-generational team of teens, college students, young adults, and senior adults who will grow and develop the Café program into your own! Come share your knowledge and experience with high school and college students and engage with your fellow peers. Meet new friends and make a lasting impact on the people you meet and the café program. Work at the café cart and facilitating activities as needed including event planning, marketing, design flyers, technology information, etc Opportunities to Volunteer Include: Cafe cart responsibilities: Setting up and closing the cafe Serving customers' orders Create smoothies, serve tea, coffee and cookies Offer board games, tablets, and technology instruction (cell phones, tablets, etc.) Interact and play games with Sirovich members and other volunteers Lead Classes of interest including Performing Arts, Crafts, etc. (optional; ie. Origami class, Acting workshop, Chinese class, Health workshop, etc.) Assist with developing and marketing new classes, programs and event planning (optional) Opportunity to enhance your skills and interests and share your knowledge to other volunteers and members! Assist with scheduled café activities including:  Game Night  Technology Night  Paint Night  Dance Party  Music Night  Monthly Events Participate in ongoing Meetings, Trainings, and Workshops: o Monthly Inter-generational Volunteer events o Monthly Cafe Advisory Committee Meetings Time Commitment: Volunteers serve flexible hours between Monday-Friday, 2:00pm-6:00pm On average, volunteers serve a minimum 2-7 of hours per week Minimum 1 day a week commitment required
10003.title: Cafe on the Mezz: Volunteer Program for Students and Older Adults!

10003.description: Girl Talk is a micro mentoring opportunity aimed towards PAL’s middle school girl s who exhibit a need to build their self-esteem and combat negative outside peer influences. Women professionals from a variety of backgrounds serve as guest speakers in workshops to impart wisdom and empower our girl s while modeling professionalism and self-respect. Topics covered throughout the program year include self-esteem and body image, leadership, civic engagement, career exploration, health and wellness, and education, among others. Currently, Girl Talk is held in PAL centers in Queens, Brooklyn, Staten Island, and the Bronx.
10003.title: Girl Talk

10003.description: Samaritans of New York operates the city’s 24-hour suicide prevention hotline. Last year, we answered over 82,000 hotline calls. Samaritans is part of a well-established international network of 400 centers in 42 countries where over 20,000 volunteers provide crisis response and emotional support services to people who are in distress, depressed and suicidal. Samaritans is currently accepting applicants for the March Hotline Training Class. If you are interested in becoming a Samaritans volunteer, please contact us to attend one of the following orientations: Tuesday, May 9 Wednesday, May 17 Thursday, May 25 To receive a Volunteer Information packet, please email samaritansnycvol@aol.com with the following information: -your full name -phone number -residential street address Or: - Inquire through our website: http://samaritansnyc.org/volunteer-2/ - Call 212-673-3041 to receive a Volunteer Information Packet by mail We look forward to hearing from you! Almost anyone who finds themselves facing some overwhelming obstacle or personal tragedy needs help getting through their moment of crisis. At Samaritans of NYC, our caring volunteers respond to people of all backgrounds: teenagers, the elderly, people dealing with chronic and terminal illnesses like cancer or AIDS; victims of violence, bullying and sexual abuse; the homeless, unemployed, veterans; those with sexual identity issues, who are trying to cope with stigma, who are hesitant to seek help. The work is challenging, the training intensive and the experience extremely rewarding! You must be focused, disciplined and keep the commitments you make. This is serious work; you’ll be joining a group of dedicated volunteers from NYC’s diverse communities who work together in a supportive environment in a convenient Village location. Volunteer requirements: Must be at least 21 Good English speaking + written skills Willing to work as part of a collaborative team Available to donate: 1 weekday morning, afternoon, evening or weekend shift a week 1 overnight shift a month No experience necessary!
10003.title: Peer Counselors Needed - Volunteer on Samaritans 24-Hour Crisis Hotline!

10003.description: Read about KittyKind at www.kittykind.org KittyKind is all-volunteer cat rescue and cat adoption group located in the Petco store on 17th Street and Broadway, in space that the Petco Corporation donates. KittyKind relies upon donations for all other expenses. It relies upon volunteers to care for the rescued cats. A Health-Maintenance volunteer helps to give nutritional supplements, eye cream, and veterinarian-prescribed medication to cats awaiting adoption at the KittyKind adoption center. Training and training materials will be given. The volunteer shift would be for a couple of hours, one day a week, throughout the year. After training, the day and the time are up to you. Preference is for a volunteer who has experience working with animals or who is a pre-vet, or a vet-tech student. However, all help is welcome. For Saturday or Sunday help, please be an \"early bird,\" able to start about 8 or 9, before the adoption center gets crowded. Must be over age 18. Active seniors very welcome! References preferred. To begin the application process, please do the following: Connect to kittykind.org Click on Volunteer Fill out an application, specifying Health Maintenance as your preference Then, someone will email you shortly after. Thanks.
10003.title: Health Care: Cats/Kittens

10003.description: We need a person(s) with a car to spend 1 hour (between 9:30 and 10:30am) on Saturdays to pick up donated food in the neighborhood from in-kind donors. We pick up from Au Bon Pain, Blimpies, Jon Vie Pasteries, Balducci's, D'Agostino's, etc. all in Soho and the Village.
10003.title: To pick up food with a car on Sat. mornings

10003.description: We feed 150 homeless and needy people every Saturday. Volunteers are invited to arrive about 9:00am until about 12:00pm to help in the preparation of food and soup by chopping vegatables, slicing bread, making sandwiches, arranging desserts, etc. No need to make a reservation - just show up and we'll put you to work although groups must be limited to 5 people please. A different group organized by NYCares serves the meals in the later afternoon. We are also in need of a person(s), with a car, to pick up food from in-kind donors in the neighborhood on Sat. mornings (ie. Sullivan Steet Bread, Knickeboker Restaurant, Chipolte, etc.) and bring the donated food to our Soup Kitchen so it can be prepared for serving. E-mail Dean directly if you can help in this endeavor.
10003.title: To help feed the needy

10037.description: We are seeking enthusiastic, creative, industrious, responsible, punctual, and best of all, creative people who can generate fun every moment of the summer day camp experience. Depending upon your experience, you will work as Teacher, Head Counselor, or Group Leader in the classroom, in offsite locations, or in the gymnasium/outdoor playground. Must have tons of energy, a willingness to make a fool of yourself for the sake of making someone smile, the ability to give \"warm fuzzies\" on a daily basis, and a desire to have FUN! If you have experience in any of the following, this camp is for you: visual art, music, dramatic art, wacky science, coding, maker faire, financial literacy, entrepreneurship, community service, activism, literacy, education, chess, juggling, sports, yoga, firethrowing, marching band, drill team, gardening, cooking, learning, sharing love with children.
10037.title: Sunny Faces Welcome! Looking For Summer Camp Counselors - NYC

10037.description: We're looking for CodeSters who have the ability, fluidity, and patience to work with students between the ages of 6-16 with instruction on app development, website development, robotics, or game development. You will be on the cutting edge of teaching computer science concepts, as less than 10% of New York City, as well as US schools have a computer science curriculum. You will utilize the existing creativity that already exists within the spirits of children, as well as their knack for apps and video games, and channel this energy into supporting them in learning wireframing, weibsite, app & game development. If you are into Scratch, Arduino, JAVA, or HTML, this is a PLUS. Come contribute your mastery to increase the interest in STEM in our students one of our Harlem locations!
10037.title: Teach Kids How To Code: Join Our Summer STEM Program In Harlem!

10037.description: The Jewish Board's Harlem Community Residence (124th SRO) provides transitional living studio apartments and mental health services for adults with mental illness. As a Yoga Instructor at our Harlem Community Residence, you will teach beginner's yoga to our residents.
10037.title: Yoga Instructor- Manhattan (Harlem)
10037.org: Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services

10037.description: The Jewish Board's Manhattan-based Adult Residence provides transitional living studio apartments and mental health services for adults with mental illnesses. As the Art Group Leader, you will lead adult clients in a structured, hands on, interactive and engaging art class! Teach basic art skills to a small group of adults and get their creative juices flowing. Art is a great avenue to help our residents at 124 th St to get back on their feet. Background in creative or visual arts preferred. This opportunity is available Monday Friday. Volunteer shifts will be from 3-5pm for at least 6 months.
10037.title: Visual Art Leader- Manhattan (Harlem)
10037.org: Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services

10166.description: We are expanding our board now that our tax exempt nonprofit organization is growing. We are looking in particular for board members with a strong background in fundraising and/or grantwriting. We have meetings on an as-needed basis, about 4 to 6 times a year. Initial commitment is through the end of 2017. Monthly time commitment will vary, averaging 10 hours or so a month. You'd be joining a high-energy diverse group of people with a can-do attitude and a great sense of humor and joy. Serving on the board means being part of the team that ensures the legal, administrative, financial, developent, and public relations run smoothly so the organization can carry out its mission. Your service on the board would help make a powerful difference in the lives of children and teens with disabilties through dance and the related arts.
10166.title: Fundraiser or Grant Writer to join Board of growing nonprofit dance organization

10165.description: Come volunteer in rural Kenya with one of our 4 humanitarian aid programs: (1) Healthcare, (2) HIV/AIDS Education, (3) Education, (4) Microenterprise Development. Volunteer Kenya / ICODEI is a non-religious, non-political volunteer organization run through a partnership of past overseas volunteers and local Kenyans. Our Microenterprise Development Program is our newest program. We have been active in helping set up small income-generating activities (IGA) for rural self-help groups since the early 2000's (primarily thru grants), but only recently began focusing our work on providing more advice, consulting assistance, and small loans to the groups. MDP volunteers work with the existing microenterprise groups to help them grow and improve their existing projects, as well as help newly forming groups start an IGA. The 5 main areas of volunteer activity in the MDP are as follows: • Progress Assessment • Facilitate a Group Project Discussion / Evaluation and Provide Project Advice • Facilitate Knowledge and Resource Sharing Within the Network of Groups • Provide Small Loans • Provide General Business Skills Training Seminars Most volunteers spend their time doing a combination of all the above 5 items. Our value-added is not just in the form of providing financial resources (loans) but includes project planning advice, basic management and accounting training, and (very importantly) volunteers act as facilitators between our vast network of groups in order to facilitate knowledge and resource sharing among the groups. Our pilot microlending program has just gotten off the ground during the last several months and we currently have about $10,000 USD in outstanding loans. The MDP volunteers will be spending a lot of their time over the next several months meeting with the loans groups to ensure that are on schedule with paying back their loans and that they are investing their money prudently (e.g., in productivity enhancing resources versus consumption items). As the loans are repaid, the volunteers then give them out in the form of new loans to other groups. We have a very large backlog of loan application requests. As a volunteer in the MDP you would spend the vast majority of your time out in the field meeting and working with the women microenterprise groups, which is a very rewarding and educational experience. All of the microenterprise groups within our network are independent groups. We do not manage their day to day operations and do not charge any type of fee for our services. We are a strict volunteer non-for-profit organization. All interest that we receive from the microloans goes towards new loans for additional groups. We are now have a network of around 100 microenterprise groups within the western Kenya region. As of June 2007, our organization has had over 350 volunteers since 1998 from over 6 different countries. Volunteers in our Microenterprise Development have come from a variety of backgrounds including undergrad business students (Duke, Rice, Miami, Indiana), MBA and graduate students on their summer break (Stanford, Penn, etc.), management consultants (BCG, McKinsey, CRA), retired professionals, and accountants. Check out our website at www.volunteerkenya.org
10165.title: Business Consultants in Africa

10043.description: 2017: Fifteenth Annual Drums Along the Hudson A Native American and Multicultural Celebration Sunday, June 4th, 2017- Inwood Hill Park 11am to 6pm - Rain or Shine. FREE The 15th Annual DRUMS ALONG THE HUDSON(r): A Native American and Multicultural Celebration will take place on Sunday, June 4th, 2017 in Upper Manhattan’s Inwood Hill Park from 11:00 am until 6:00 pm, rain or shine. This event is free to the public and is presented by Lotus Music & Dance in collaboration with the New York City Department of Parks & Recreation, sponsored in part by the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs and the New York City Councilmember Ydanis Rodriguez. The host for the event will be Sandra Bookman, weekend anchor for WABC-TV and host of \"Here and Now\". The afternoon host will be Patrick Riley Pop Culture Expert/Blogger. During the day, we take time to honor individuals and organizations for their contributions to environmental and humanitarian causes. This year, Yvonne Wakim Dennis, Executive Director of the Children’s Cultural Center of Native America will be our honoree.
10043.title: "Drums Along the Hudson: A Native American & Multicultural Celebration"

10044.description: The Girls on the Run 5k is a non-competitive event that marks the end of our 10 week curriculum and celebrates a season of learning about the importance of taking care of our emotional and physical health. As the culminating event of the Girls on the Run curriculum, it is a moment that beautifully reflects the very essence of the program goals and truly embodies our mission of inspiring girls to be joyful, healthy and confident. We believe that accomplishment comes in all flavors and that everyone who participates - whether they run, walk, hop, skip or cartwheel across the finish line - is to be honored and congratulated. We invite you to join us in this season of celebration! We are excited to announce we are back on Roosevelt Island for our Spring 2017 season! With our program growth, Girls on the Run NYC will be hosting an incredible 5k event for our largest season ever on Sunday, June 4. Your support as a runner or volunteer - whether a parent, teacher, friend or fan - is so important to helping our girls cross the Finish Line with confidence. Our 5k course will have us running the perimeter of Roosevelt Island with beautiful views the entire way. 5k Run/Walk Options: Sparkle Runner ( $35 registration fee): Sparkle Runners will be paired with one of our Girls on the Run teams and will get the chance to run the course, cheering for all of the girls! Open to all females 18 or older. 5k Runner ($30 registration fee for those under 18; $35 registration fee for 18 & up). This category is for any adult and youth participants who would like to run/walk this fun, non-timed 5k, including siblings & friends of our girls! All runners receive a 5k shirt! 5k Volunteer Info: We invite you to join us in this season of celebration! As girls from across our area come together to achieve their goals on 5k day, they will be depending on volunteers like you to help them shine! Below are descriptions of our volunteer needs: Activity Stations: Activity station volunteers help generate excitement for the girls and families before the 5k with the happy hair station and the photo booth. (35 Volunteers) -Happy Hair: volunteers help girls and families get GOTR-ized before the race with colored hair spray. -Photo Booth volunteers help girls, coaches and families capture the joy of the day. All smiles at this station! Course Marshal: Course Marshal volunteers will serve as cheerleaders along the girls and their running buddies! They will also help to ensure safety of all participants. (150 Volunteers) Field Set-up: Field Team volunteers assist with set-up and breakdown of team site flags, tables and water near the finish line. (35 Volunteers ) Registration: Registration volunteers help check-in runners & distribute t-shirts and bibs to 5k participants [non-program participant runners]. (15 Volunteers) Water Station: Water Station volunteers hand out water to participants and encourage them along the way. (30 Volunteers) To learn more about how to run the 5k with us, visit gotrnyc.org/5kinfo.
10044.title: Girls on the Run NYC Spring 5K

10044.description: Objective Be The Match Board of Ambassadors (BoA) is an integral part of our fundraising efforts, serving as representatives of Be The Match within the community to identify, engage and build relationships with individuals and corporations in support of the Be The Match Soiree event to advance our lifesaving mission. Attributes * Individuals of affluence and/or influence in the community * Strong interest in fundraising and charitable giving * Well respected in the community and/or their individual networks * Goal oriented * Has an affinity for Be The Match mission Responsibilities** ** in collaboration with Development Manager and Be The Match Foundation * Actively engage in raising $5,000 in sponsorship, attendees and/or contributions * Collaborate with BoA to identify and coordinate fundraising asks * Support the mission and activities of Be The Match Foundation as a representative, relationship builder and recognition provider * Promote Soiree event through personal and professional network * Identify additional leaders to join BoA * Attend monthly BoA meetings * Provide input and ownership in the Be The Match Soiree development plan Our Board of Ambassadors will be recognized at the Be The Match Soiree, on our Be The Match Soiree materials program and the Be The Match Annual Report.
10044.title: Be The Match New York Soiree Board of Ambassadors

10009.description: We are no accepting applications for Civic Art Lab 2017. Please fill in this form no later than May 15th : http://bit.ly/2nIPDDH Civic Art Lab is a pop-up gallery and workshop space on the Lower East Side at Avenue C & 7th Street, hosted by GreenspaceNYC. For our third year, we return to the Lower East Side. Our 3 day lab themes include sustainability and design; creative re-use; mapping and neighborhood placemaking; urban agriculture; sustainable architecture; health & well-being; and environmental justice, to name a few. Please fill out the following form to apply. Call for submissions is open between April 1st and May 15th, 2017. For additional questions, please email laura@greenspacenyc.org and jeff@greenspacenyc.org.
10009.title: Civic Art Lab 2017 |  Call for workshops, talks, and pop-up exhibitions | LES

10009.description: Volunteer with the LES Ecology Center's summer education programs! Help out with fishing clinics, open hours at the Environmental Learning Center, field trips, and more. Opportunties available on weekends, evenings, and weekdays. Fishing or environmental education experience is great but not necessary. Volunteers should be able to attend one of two training dates- either Sunday 5/21 4:30pm or Thursday 5/25 at 6pm.
10009.title: Summer Education Program Volunteers

10009.description: Go the extra mile with Back on My Feet NYC! Dedicated teams of volunteers run 2-4 miles with our members who are transitioning out of homelessness. We encourage runners of all speeds to become a part of our community! Team ABC runs/jogs/walks with Pride Site & The Bowery Mission every Monday, Wednesday, and Friday from 5:30-6:30AM. To find out more and sign up for an orientation, visit nyc.backonmyfeet.org/nyc-run-with-us
10009.title: Lower East Side Morning Runner

10009.description: S.O.S. Gamers is a not-for-profit 501(c)(3) organization dedicated to bridging the gap in technology and information for lower income residents living in New York City. We are currently seeking individuals to work with us as staff in our Youth Video Gaming League. The activities take place at the East 12th St School & Campos Plaza in the Lower East Side of Manhattan. The league provides an opportunity for youth to play video games in a safe, structured setting while acquiring valuable life skills such as teamwork, communication and sportsmanship. We are looking for volunteers for these roles: Activity Specialist/Coaches - Simply put, coaches aim to ensure that while the players are having a great time playing the game, they're also actively implementing the basic fundamentals of teamwork. In some cases, we're indeed role models for our youth, so this role requires knowledge and patience and great team building skills. Event Staff - Our larger scale events, such as gaming tournaments, require staff with particular skill sets to ensure that they run smoothly. These roles are: Event Coordinators, Sign-in Coordinators, Tournament Organizers, Station Managers, Game Casters/Commentary, Stream Managers, Photographers/Videographers We are also looking for individuals to assist with our Marketing (Online and In-Person) efforts as well as Graphic Designers. Scheduling for the COACH role is as follows: Monday - Day Program 4:30 - 6PM, Night Program 6 - 9 PM Tuesday - Day Program 4:30 - 6PM Thursday - Day Program 4:30 - 6PM Friday Day Program 1:15 - 6PM, Night Program 6 - 9 PM Sat - All ages 10AM - 6PM Volunteers need not be available all days, but will need to be available for an entire block of hours, i.e. Tuesday 4:30 - 6PM for the full 1.5 hours. All event staff roles will be scheduled during the Saturday - All Ages 10am - 6PM block of time. Marketing and Graphic Design are on an as needed basis around your schedule. Ideal candidate requirements include: A familiarity with current generation video gaming equipment, in particular, the Nintendo Wii U and Super Smash Bros. Wii U. A high comfort level with working around children and teens ages 13 Great social and organizational skills (facilitating small tournaments and other organized gaming activities) The ability to be flexible and adaptable as required Please send an email to SOS@SOSGamers.org AND ALewisHall@SOSGamers.org and include the role(s) you're interested in as well as a resume/job/education history. Regsitering with the our partner school through the Department of Education will be required. Thank you!
10009.title: You Game? Join our Youth Video Gaming League!

10009.description: CBSBB’s mentoring program enables young people to expand their horizons, their hopes and their dreams. It helps inspire them to improve academic performance and reduce risky behavior, which ultimately leads to stable health, strong personal relationships and gainful employment. You should know that research has proven that CBSBB’s integration of mentoring, family counseling and skill building ensures that our mentoring relationships are healthier and last longer than the national average. CBSBB’s target populations are children from first generation, low-income communities. Many of the families we work with are overwhelmed by multiple stressors. Poverty, a shortage of skills and a lack of exposure to opportunities are some of the issues our mentees face every day. These children are eager to expand their horizons and having a mentor can be the difference between their current reality and a successful future. You can be that difference! MENTOR ROLE: Maintain a one-to-one match relationship between yourself as the Big Sister/Brother (mentor) and your Little (mentee) while respecting the family system Serve as a positive role model and friend while helping your mentee to set and accomplish goals Build the match relationship by planning and participating in activities together PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS: Be at least 21 years of age Be interested in working with a young girl or boy between the ages of 10-18 Be willing to finance all match outings (outings need not be expensive) If child doesn’t travel alone, be responsible for picking up or dropping of your Little Sister/Brother TIME COMMITMENT: Mentors must meet fact-to-face with their mentees for 8 hours each month and go on outings with their mentee. Typically matches meet twice a month, for an average of 4 hours each, usually on weekends, for a minimum of one year Mentors are responsible for maintaining communication with their mentee in between outings by setting up a weekly call night to help build their match relationship Matches must attend at least one skill learning program workshop series per year TO APPLY: Visit www.cbsbb.org/volunteers or call us at 212 475-3291 x502.
10009.title: Change a Life.  Change Your Life.  Become a Mentor!

10009.description: Our Manhattan based organization is seeking a cohort of approximately 12 volunteers who would work with our homeless population on a scheduled rotating basis in teams of two or three workers weekly to assist us with intakes, assessments and referrals. Our hours of operation are every Saturday from 8 AM to 3:00PM and we are located at 137 East Second Street, (at Avenue A in Manhattan) at the Cardinal Spellman Center (lower level). 2nd Avenue stop on the F train. Our space is equipped with wireless Internet, computers and printers and a full supply of stationary for volunteers to assist our guests. All volunteers would have a tremendous amount of staff support. Please have the interested parties contact Joe Montano, Director at 347-534-7792 or through email at emailucss-ny@yahoo.com
10009.title: Volunteers needed to provide homeless with social services.

10012.description: Contact the volunteer coordinator at volunteer@housingworksbookstore.org with any questions or to sign up. Please include the name of the organization you work with and how many volunteers you hope to sign up for the opportunity. Please do not contact us through VolunteerMatch. Thanks for you interest in supporting us for Housing Works Bookstore Cafe's annual Open Air Street Fair! The Open Air Street Fair is our daylong block party and shopping bazaar along Crosby Street, between Houston and Prince. Featuring thousands of donated books, records, and CDs for $1 each; live music presented by Two Boots Americana Jamboree; food specials from our Bookstore Cafe, and unique finds from our Soho Thrift Shop. This event is a can’t-miss start to the summer, and all to support a great cause. This is sure to be a great event and we look forward to sharing the experience with you! We currently have three shift openings: Morning Team: 9:30 am to 1:30 pm This is a customer-facing opportunity, where you will be helping shoppers as well as restocking books. Afternoon Team: 1:00 pm-5:00 pm This is a customer-facing opportunity, where you will be helping shoppers as well as restocking books. Event Break-Down Team: 4:00 pm-7:00 pm This group of volunteers help us clean up following the Street Fair, including packing up books and some additional light cleaning.
10012.title: Help Housing Works out at our Annual Outdoor Street Fair on June 11th!

10012.description: Housing Works Bookstore and Cafe is an entrepreneurial arm of Housing Works, a New York non-profit whose mission is to end the dual crises of homelessness and AIDS through relentless advocacy, the provision of lifesaving services, and entrepreneurial businesses that sustain our efforts. All of the books we sell are donated by members of the community, and a majority of the people that work in the bookstore are volunteers. You can find out more about Housing Works' mission, services, and advocacy by visiting our website: http://www.housingworks.org/ We are looking for a group of volunteers to help us out with our annual inventory on Friday, June 30th. This is a crucial activity for the continued running of the Bookstore Cafe, and we would love to have your group participate! Members of your group will help us keep track of our stock of each and every one of our books. This is a great opportunity to explore a variety of different books, as well as enjoy the atmosphere of the Bookstore Cafe at a time when it will be closed to the public. We are currently looking for groups of around 10 people for two shifts: 10 am to 2 pm and 1:30-5:30. We are flexible in terms of scheduling, so if these shifts do not work for your oranization, please contact the volunteer coordinator, and we can set up a time that works best for you. Please contact the volunteer coordinator at volunteer@housingworksbookstore.org if you are interested or have any questions!
10012.title: Group Volunteer Activity at the Housing Works Bookstore Cafe on Friday, June 30th

10012.description: Esperanza is dedicated to keeping young people at home with their families. We work to safely reduce reliance on out-of-home placement for court-involved youth by offering a community-based alternative to incarceration throughout the five boroughs of New York City. Esperanza began delivering direct services in 2002 and currently serves young people who are prosecuted in Family Court as well as youth who are being prosecuted as adults in Supreme/Criminal Court. Our home-based, direct-service program includes up to six months of intensive therapy for youth and their families, as well as case and crisis management. Towards the end of this period, some of our participants are matched with mentors for a period of time to further support the work they have done while in Esperanza. Esperanza NY, Inc. is looking for individuals to mentor youth. Interested applicants must have a passion for working with young people and the ability to build positive relationships with them. This is a volunteer opportunity.

10012.description: Come volunteer in rural Kenya with one of our 4 humanitarian aid programs: (1) Healthcare, (2) HIV/AIDS Education, (3) Education, (4) Microenterprise Development. Volunteer Kenya - ICODEI is a non-religious, non-political volunteer organization run through a partnership of past overseas volunteers and local Kenyans. Our Microenterprise Development Program is our newest program. We have been active in helping set up small income-generating activities (IGA) for rural self-help groups since the early 2000's (primarily thru grants), but only recently began focusing our work on providing more advice, consulting assistance, and small loans to the groups. MDP volunteers work with the existing microenterprise groups to help them grow and improve their existing projects, as well as help newly forming groups start an IGA. The 5 main areas of volunteer activity in the MDP are as follows: • Progress Assessment • Facilitate a Group Project Discussion / Evaluation and Provide Project Advice • Facilitate Knowledge and Resource Sharing Within the Network of Groups • Provide Small Loans • Provide General Business Skills Training Seminars Most volunteers spend their time doing a combination of all the above 5 items. Our value-added is not just in the form of providing financial resources (loans) but includes project planning advice, basic management and accounting training, and (very importantly) volunteers act as facilitators between our vast network of groups in order to facilitate knowledge and resource sharing among the groups. Our pilot microlending program has just gotten off the ground during the last several months and we currently have about $10,000 USD in outstanding loans. The MDP volunteers will be spending a lot of their time over the next several months meeting with the loans groups to ensure that are on schedule with paying back their loans and that they are investing their money prudently (e.g., in productivity enhancing resources versus consumption items). As the loans are repaid, the volunteers then give them out in the form of new loans to other groups. We have a very large backlog of loan application requests. As a volunteer in the MDP you would spend the vast majority of your time out in the field meeting and working with the women microenterprise groups, which is a very rewarding and educational experience. All of the microenterprise groups within our network are independent groups. We do not manage their day to day operations and do not charge any type of fee for our services. We are a strict volunteer non-for-profit organization. All interest that we receive from the microloans goes towards new loans for additional groups. We are now have a network of around 100 microenterprise groups within the western Kenya region. As of June 2007, our organization has had over 350 volunteers since 1998 from over 6 different countries. Volunteers in our Microenterprise Development have come from a variety of backgrounds including undergrad business students (Duke, Rice, Miami, Indiana), MBA and graduate students on their summer break (Stanford, Penn, etc.), management consultants (BCG, McKinsey, CRA), retired professionals, and accountants. Check out our website at www.volunteerkenya.org
10012.title: Microenterprise Development in Africa

In order to provide this very special service, we need enthusiastic, friendly volunteers who can act as servers, busboys, waiters and more. Locations vary throughout the city.

10278.description: Score NYC is the local chapter servicing the NYC business community. We have over 90 members. Currently we are seeking a dynamic digital marketing professional, to lead our digital efforts. Volunteering at SCORE is one of the ways for you to give back to our community, stay connected with business leaders, and use your knowledge and expertise to bring SCORE’s resources to the next generation of entrepreneurs in your community. We hope to hear from you. RESPONSIBILITIES: Partner with the Marketing Chair in formulating a high impact, multi-channel marketing program Lead digital advertising initiative on Google Adwords and Facebook to increase workshop attendance, mentoring clientele, participation at major trade events, and volunteer signup Monitor, analyze and optimize ad performance and landing page effectiveness to maximize ROI Develop and lead a content marketing strategy; work with key constituents to create content and publish to our blog and other relevant platforms Manage our local chapter website and analyze web traffic to improve user experience and optimize for search and conversion Help create and lead an internal team of volunteers to execute and sustain this initiative VOLUNTEER REQUIREMENTS - 3+ years of experience creating, implementing, and tracking results of a targeted digital marketing program Fluency with Wordpress, Google Analytics, Hootsuite; Familiarity with SEOMoz, Leadpages, RiteTag, Semrush, etc.; Knowledge of HTML/CSS a plus Experienced in blogging, use of Google Adwords and paid ads on Facebook Attendance at marketing committee meetings, usually 2 hours each, once a month, at 26 Federal Plaza NYC, during business week Time commitment of 8-10 hours per week. Work is flexible and can be done virtually. TO APPLY - Email to: VOLUNTEERNOW@scorenyc.org ** your resume, a brief note regarding the number of hours you could volunteer each week AND please let us know the days and times you are NOT available. Any personal information you feel would help us get to know you better, including the circumstances that allow you to volunteer at this point in your life. Best day and time for you to come in to meet our team Your contact information ** Interviews for this position will be conducted by MARY TAN so please email both volunteernow@scorenyc.org and tan@scorenyc.org
10278.title: Volunteer - Digital Strategist

10278.description: Volunteer Opportunity for: Corporate Directors and Senior Management Consultants Position: Practice Leader, Advisory Board Practice to Small to Medium-size Enterprises in Manhattan, Brooklyn and The Bronx. Background: For over 50 years, SCORE Mentors have been providing counsel and assistance to thousands of entrepreneurs and small business owners across New York City. Some SCORE client firms have grown to the point that they need to add outside perspective and expertise to help them shape their business strategy and to keep them looking beyond managing their companies on a day to day basis to focus on the broader picture. SCORE NYC seeks to recruit an experienced corporate director or management consultant to create this practice. Responsibilities: With the ability to schedule this SCORE volunteer commitment around your available time, and working closely with SCORE NYC's senior leadership: Lead the effort to develop this Advisory Board practice; including identifying contacting, and persuading established businesses that they in fact would be well served by creating an Advisory Board Create ideal candidate profiles for members of the Advisory Board team; Build a roster of potential Advisory Board members from the current roster of SCORE Interview Mentors and qualified external recruits; Create practices and standards necessary to build a resource that will serve SCORE NYC's clients with distinction; Serve on one or multiple Advisory Boards in order to set a high level of service to SCORE's clients; Contribute to the strength and growth of SCORE New York through adding your management expertise to this totally volunteer organization. Ideal Candidate Profile: 30+ years as a business leader; Senior experience in general management, or on board(s) of directors, or in management consulting; An ability to quickly assess business opportunities and problems; Excellent listening skills and the ability to act as a responsible advisor; Ability to establish rapport with successful entrepreneurs and small business leaders. A real desire to help others succeed. Compensation: Volunteering at SCORE is one of the ways for you to give back to your community, connect with fellow business leaders, and pass on your knowledge and expertise to the next generation of entrepreneurs in your community. Enjoy the satisfaction of contributing to the success of others; Share great experience with other SCORE volunteers and make new friends; Provide leadership for the local business community; Participate in life-long learning, growing professionally and personally. To learn more about SCORE NYC, go to www.newyorkcity.scorenyc.org and If you’d like to discuss this opportunity to serve the New York business community: EMAIL: humanresources@scorenyc.org or CALL: Diane Drey, Score NYC Chapter Chair at 212-264-4507
10278.title: Volunteer - Advisory Board Member - for established businesses

10278.description: We are looking for an organized computer literate person who can assist in the prepartion and administration of the business workshops we put on annually for entrepreneurs. In addition to helping us you will have the opportunity to attend the workshops for free - so this is perfect opportunity for someone that is interested in going into business or having a business career. The workshops offerings cover 25 subject areas including marketing and sales, finance and accounting, leadership and management, and industry specific workshops. The Workshop Committee, which organizes these educational experiences needs qualified volunteer with event planning skills to participate in the team effort. AS EVENT COORDINATOR YOUR RESPONSIBILITIES ARE: Prepare the materials which will be distributed at the workshops Arrive at the workshop 45 minutes in advance to Meet and Greet the participants, check them in Make sure participants have paid the proper fee Collect and tally surveys on the workshop Prepare statistical information Introduce speakers (optional) REQUIREMENTS We seek individuals who can CONSISTENTLY volunteer four hours a week. Workshops are primarily given during the business day, although some are in the early evening.

10278.description: We have an immediate opening for an administrative assistant to support our non-profit organization that mentors small businesses and start-ups. This is a key role because it is often the first point of contact for clients and volunteers visiting or calling our main offices. It also provides important support for the Membership and Workshop Committees. Responsibilities include - answering the telephone, - preparing promotional material, - responding to client inquiries, - assisting with workshop registrations - attending events and meeting and greeting prospective clients - assisting the mentors with a variety of administrative and computer tasks. We seek individuals who can consistently commit to at least one \"five hours per week\" at our downtown office. By joining our organization you will be making a significant contribution to New York City's small business community.
10278.title: Volunteer Administrative Assistant and Reception

10035.description: Reading Partners needs volunteers like you to provide students in under-resourced elementary schools in your community with the proven, individualized reading support they need to read at grade level by fourth grade. Reading is the foundation for all future learning.The ability to read transforms lives and can empower children to reach their full potential. Research shows that when students can read at grade level by fourth grade, they have a greater opportunity to succeed in school and in life. With your help, we can equip students with the foundational skills they need to read at grade level. Each week, you will meet one-on-one with your student every week to help them develop strong literacy skills and discover a passion for reading. We'll provide a structured curriculum, in-person training, and ongoing support to help your student thrive. Rigorous research has proven that Reading Partners significantly increases reading proficiency. No teaching experience required and anyone over the age of 14 can volunteer. Flexible Monday to Thursday volunteer times between 9am and 5pm. Visit our website at www.readingpartners.org/volunteer to sign up and learn more.
10035.title: Become a reading partner- make a lifelong impact on a child (PS 7 Samuel Stern, Manhattan)
