Volunteers are an integral component of the Carter Burden Network's 40+ years of success. No matter your age, experience or schedule, CBCAcan accommodate your needs to ensure that you have a meaningful and effective volunteer experience. The Friendly Visiting program matches volunteers with seniors who share common interests and hobbies for social interaction. Volunteers participate in visits at least twice a month (for 1-2 hours) in a senior's home and may chat, play a game, read a book, take a walk (if the senior is able), or another activity. The Friendly Visiting program is an on-going opportunity. We are looking for a compassionate, patient, and committed volunteer comfortable engaging with a deaf senior living in the Upper East Side. Time is flexible but we are looking for a volunteer available in the afternoons (preferably between noon and 6pm). If you are interested in this opportunity and would like to learn more about Kitty, please email us at: volunteer@carterburdennetwork.org
10029.title: Become a friendly visitor!

10029.description: Join New York Common Pantry's Hot Meals program in it's fight to end hunger! Every week day morning, we serve a healthy hot breakfast to 200 food insecure guests. All of our meals are cooked in our kitchen on site, our staff cook prepares hearty balanced meals with whole some ingredients. Our dining room offers participants a chance to eat, sit, and socialize in a relaxing, safe, friendly atmosphere that offers a retreat from the tension of being homelewss or living in poverty. To serve breakfast we need your help on Monday or Tuesday from 7:30 to 9:30 am distributing tray, serving hot or cold food and drinks, collecting guest information, replenishing supplies, and washing dishes.
10029.title: Help Serve Breakfast at New York Common Pantry

10029.description: Are you a certified fitness instructor looking to give back to your community? Shape Up New York is a free fitness program for all ages and is looking for Fitness instructors like you in the Queens area. Volunteer opportunities are available for a variety of classes and activities, including zumba, yoga and pilates. Volunteers must have some experience as a fitness instructor, and once accepted, will have the opportunity to shadow a current instructor before leading their own classes. This position offers flexibility and creativity for enthusiastic volunteers interested in giving back to their communities and addressing pressing health issues such as Diabetes and Obesity.
10029.title: Fitness Instructors Needed in Queens

10029.description: Looking for volunteers looking to learn how to coach basketball and to help professional coaching staff with growing our program in the city.
10029.title: Volunteers needed for youth basketball program in Manhattan

10029.description: Harlem RBI, an award winning youth development program, is seeking volunteer tutors to provide academic support to middle school students in East Harlem and the South Bronx start in the fall of 2016. Tutors work with youth individually and in small groups to help improve student success in class, increase subject-specific retention, and contribute to overall academic development. What You'll Do Lead weekly tutoring sessions supported by staff and volunteers; Support participants with homework completion in a middle school subject of your choice, including: English, Math, Science, and Social Studies; Serve as a role model and build positive relationships with youth; What We're Looking For Strong command of one or more of the following academic subjects: English, Math, Science, and/or Social Studies Previous experience working with youth; Possess creativity, enthusiasm and patience; Solid oral communication skills; Ability to make a consistent, weekly commitment; Bachelor's Degree (a plus). 1-2 years previous tutoring experience (a plus); 1-2 years teaching experience (a major plus); Benefits Gain invaluable experience and opportunities for professional development at an award winning youth development program; Receive an optional professional reference upon completion of your service term; Join an incredible community of passionate staff and volunteers. Hours: At least one 2 hour to 2.5 hour session per week, Monday-Thursday. Times vary between 4:00pm and 6:30pm, based on youth/volunteer availability and program schedule. Commitment: At least 3 months, beginning in fall of 2016. Harlem RBI provides equal opportunity for all volunteers. Apply here: http://careers.harlemrbi.org/careers/position/volunteer-tutor-east-harlem-ny
10029.title: Make A Difference- Tutor A Middle School Student!

10029.description: Harlem RBI, an award winning youth development program, is seeking volunteer tutors to provide subject-specific academic support to our middle school students in East Harlem and the South Bronx. Tutors work with youth individually and in small groups to help improve student success in class, increase subject-specific retention, and contribute to overall academic development. What You’ll Do Lead weekly tutoring sessions supported by staff and volunteers; Support participants with homework completion in a middle school subject of your choice, including: English, Math, Science, and Social Studies; Serve as a role model and build positive relationships with youth; What We’re Looking For Strong command of one or more of the following academic subjects: English, Math, Science, and/or Social Studies Previous experience working with youth; Possess creativity, enthusiasm and patience; Solid oral communication skills; Ability to make a consistent, weekly commitment; Bachelor’s Degree (a plus). 1-2 years previous tutoring experience (a plus); 1-2 years teaching experience (a major plus); Benefits Gain invaluable experience and opportunities for professional development at an award winning youth development program; Receive an optional professional reference upon completion of your service term; Join an incredible community of passionate staff and volunteers. Hours: At least one 2 hour to 2.5 hour session per week, Monday-Thursday. Times vary between 4:00pm and 6:30pm, based on youth/volunteer availability and program schedule. Commitment: At least 3 months. Harlem RBI provides equal opportunity for all volunteers. Apply here: http://careers.harlemrbi.org/careers/position/volunteer-tutor-east-harlem-ny
10029.title: Volunteer Tutor

10029.description: Harlem RBI, an award winning youth development program, is seeking volunteer coaches to work with youth between the ages of 11-18 in practices and games. Coaches teach baseball/softball and provide youth with opportunities to play, learn, and grow, inspiring them to recognize their potential and realize their dreams. Each coach serves as a member of a team made up of coaches and managers. Harlem RBI volunteer coaches can have a direct and meaningful impact on the positive development of the youth they coach. The ideal candidate is passionate about youth development, has played and/or coached baseball/softball, and is an effective communicator. Roles and Responsibilities * Coach youth in technical skills, teambuilding and personal development; * Lead practices, facilitate team meetings and attend professional development trainings; * Provide a positive, team-based environment focused on teaching baseball, softball and life skills; * Attend 1 weeknight practice and 1 weekend game each week during the season. Qualifications * Passionate about youth development; * Understanding of the power of teamwork; * Ability to create a positive, team-based environment focused on teaching baseball/softball; * Organizational skills, energy and flexibility; * Solid oral communication skills; * Ability to commit to the coaching position for at least one full season; * Baseball/Softball playing or coaching experience for ages 13 and up; * Experience with inner-city coaching (a plus); * At least 18 years of age. Hours Time commitment varies by age group but is generally 4-8 hours/week. Practices (weeknights) typically last 1.5 hours and games (weekends) last between 2-5 hours. The coaching staff of a Harlem RBI team consists of up to five adult volunteers: a manager and four coaches.
10029.title: Volunteer Baseball and Softball Coach

10029.description: Want to help make your community healthier? Volunteer to be a fitness instructor for Shape Up NYC! Shape Up organizes free fitness classes across New York City, particularly in neighborhoods with high rates of obesity and diabetes. We are looking for a dedicated fitness instructors to teach a Tai Chi class in Queens. Volunteers must be certified in Tai Chi group fitness and, once accepted, will have the opportunity to shadow a current instructor before leading their own classes.
10029.title: Tai Chi Instructor Needed in

10029.description: Do you enjoy interacdting with young toddlers? We need Classroom Aides for our Early Childhood Parent and Child Development Program, which is a classroom setting for moms and toddlers. Volunteer will interact with moms/toddlers to support an interacdtive learning setting. Art activities, musica activities and other activities serve to support the leanring needs of the child and foster bonding between parent and child. Hours needed: 3 sessions a day available between Monday and Friday: 9:30 - 11:30 am 12:30 - 2:30 pm 3:00 - 5:00 pm Bilingual helpful, but not necessary.
10029.title: URGENT! We need Classrooms Aides for our Early Childhood Socialization Program

10029.description: The Carter Burden Network is dedicated to supporting the efforts of older people to remain in their homes living independently, safely, and with dignity. Volunteers are an integral component of the Carter Burden Network’s 40+ years of success. No matter your age, experience or schedule, CBN can accommodate your needs to ensure that you have a meaningful and effective volunteer experience. Every month, over 150 seniors benefit from the food pantry in partnership with the New York Common Pantry. While we organize a distribution on site at the Carter Burden/Leonard Covello Senior Program, we also facilitate the process for the seniors who are unable to come to the main site to pick up their bags of food. Volunteers will facilitate pantry operations by: Packing about 150 small bags of food with different types of items depending on the shopping list. The pantry goods may include juice, milk, cans, cereals etc. All the items are delivered in the morning by the NY Common Pantry and a room is set up to pack the bags and organize different stations. Loading the bags of food into our van to be delivered to another senior center. This project takes place the 1st Wednesday of the month at our Adult Social Day Program located at 301 East 99th Street, New York, NY 10029. Volunteers are needed from 9am to 10-30am. They should be able to lift 12-15 pounds. A Volunteer Coordinator is on site to coordinate the volunteers. This volunteer opportunity is adapted for groups (up to 10 people). Individuals or smaller groups are also welcomed. If you are interested in this volunteer opportunity, please contact us at: volunteer@carterburdennetwork.org
10029.title: Food Pantry Volunteers

10029.description: The City Tutors (CT) is looking for volunteer tutors to provide academic support to Harlem RBI's after school program. You would be supporting middle school students with their homework during their study group hours, once a week, any day between Monday-Thursday from 4PM-6PM, or twice a week from 4-5PM or 5-6PM. As a tutor, you will have the chance to work with a small group and collaborate with the site coordinator to improve the program as a whole. To apply, you must: Have received an A- or A in the introduction to the subject course you are applying to tutor. Have a GPA at or above 3.2, or have received a degree recently. Be willing to complete 11.5 hours of College Reading and Learning Aligned (CRLA) training at City College of New York. All tutors are also expected to complete a four session comprehensive, professional training regimen. 6 hours of live training, plus another hour and a half for orientation. This is a commitment of 7.5 hours of in person training, and 4 hours of supplemental training for a total of 11.5 hours of training over the course of the Spring semester. We can accommodate your schedule for the training sessions. CT's tutoring program has been successful in helping students gain access to support that they otherwise would not have received, given their limited time spent on campus. Having tutors in these sessions early in the semester will allow us to employ strategies to reduce withdrawals and student failure rates. Your work with us would help the students’ overall subject area performance, and help us improve this educational support model, reaching more students and departments with comprehensive academic support. Learn more about Harlem RBI here: http://www.harlemrbi.org/
10029.title: Support Middle School Students with Their Homework at Harlem RBI

10029.description: Go the extra mile with Back on My Feet NYC's Team Bowery North! Dedicated teams of volunteers run 2-4 miles with our members who are transitioning out of homelessness. We encourage runners of all speeds to become a part of our community! Team Bowery North meets at 315 E 115th St. every Monday, Wednesday, and Friday from 5:45-6:45AM. To find out more and sign up for an orientation, visit nyc.backonmyfeet.org/nyc-run-with-us
10029.title: East Harlem Morning Runner

10029.description: Become a College Mentor and Make a Difference in a High School Student’s Life! East Harlem Tutorial Program’s (EHTP) goal is to help prepare students with the academic skills, strength of character and social and emotional well-being to excel in high school and college, to lead in their communities, and realize their best possible selves. The College Mentoring Program is one way we work towards achieving our goal. The College Mentoring Program is two-year, one-on-one program that guides high school scholars through the entire college admissions process and supports them as they navigate their first year of college. The program’s goal is to ensure that each senior successfully applies to college, finds financial aid, and chooses the school that is best suited for their needs. Mentor Responsibilities: - Assist your mentee in developing a list of \"best fit\" colleges by conducting online research - Assist your mentee in developing and proofreading a personal statement, as well as other short essays. - Assist your mentee in filling out and submitting applications on time. - Assist your mentee in organizing and developing a resume. - Help prepare the student for college interviews. - Assist your mentee in identifying, researching and applying for scholarships. - Act as a role model, resource, and support system to your mentee. - Support your mentee as they transition into and through their first year of college. Competencies of a Successful Mentor - Extreme locus of control - mentor goes above and beyond to meet goals and is action-oriented. - Excellent project manager - mentor is highly organized, can articulate a system for keeping track of responsibilities and meeting deadlines, and has a willingness and desire to do the research necessary to develop list of \"best fit\" schools for mentee. - Strong influencer/motivator - builds relationships quickly, is a great listener, inspires trust, and has a strong ability to influence and motivate people to desired outcomes. - Mission Fit - Passionate about EHTP’s mission of preparing students with the academic skills, strength of character, and emotional well-being to excel in high school and college, to lead in their communities, and to realize their best possible selves Time Commitment: The College Mentoring program is a two-year commitment with different requirements in Years One & Two. Year One: support your mentee with the college admissions process through weekly meetings in East Harlem (minimum of 90 minutes once per week, Tuesday or Wednesday evenings) Year Two: organize a monthly email or phone call with your mentee to provide support and guidance during their first year of college (minimum of 30 minutes once per month)
10029.title: Become a College Mentor and Make a Difference in a High School Student's Life!

10029.description: The PACT (Preventable Admissions Care Team) Volunteer Program utilizes volunteers to assist with essential, non-clinical tasks; allowing PACT workers to focus on a patient’s clinical needs. Tasks include, but are not limited to: Researching community resources for patients Scheduling appointments and transportation Performing telephone advocacy on patient behalf in regards to community resources and entitlements as identified and explained by the PACT Social Worker Making appointment reminder calls to patients Going on runs to pharmacy or other stores to purchase items for patients Calling insurance companies and pharmacies to verify benefits Performing clerical tasks - faxing, making copies Referring patients to community resources such as Access-A-Ride and Meals on Wheels Please note there is a minimum commitment of 8 hours/week. Additionally, the PACT office is not open on weekends, therefore only weekdays shifts available. Please contact PACT.VolunteerCoordinators@mountsinai.org if you are interested in joining the PACT Volunteer Program. Thank you!
10029.title: Help individuals at high risk for hospitalization, join the PACT Volunteers Partners at Mount Sinai
10029.org: Mount Sinai Hospital: Social Work Department

10029.description: We have an urgent need for after school Home Work Help volunteers to assist school aged East Harlem children in our after school Home Work Help program. You can volunteer on either Tuesdays from 5 - 6 pm or Thursdays from 5 - 6 pm. We have a group of 25 children who receive tutoring twice a week and who come twice a week with their homework. You might assist one child during the entire session or additional children as may be needed. The children in this program are children who cannot always receive help from their parents with their homework; and so this program is very important for their school success. You can do one or both sessions a week. Please contact the Volunteer Director at tgough@lsafhs.org Thank you for your consideration!
10029.title: URGENT!  Home Work Help Volunteers Needed!

10029.description: Shape Up NYC is a free citywide fitness program operated by NYC Parks, in partnership with Empire Blue Cross Blue Shield and NYC Service that provides more than 300 free group exercise classes each week at 175 locations across the five boroughs. Want to help make your community healthier? Volunteer to be a fitness instructor for Shape Up NYC! Shape Up organizes free fitness classes across New York City, particularly in neighborhoods with high rates of obesity and diabetes. We are looking for dedicated fitness instructors who would be willing to run classes in the NYC area. Volunteers must have some experience as a fitness instructor, and once accepted, will have the opportunity to shadow a current instructor before leading their own classes. This position offers flexibility and creativity for enthusiastic volunteers interested in giving back to their communities and addressing pressing health issues. Purpose: Shape Up Volunteers are dedicated fitness instructors who teach group exercise classes in neighborhoods across all five boroughs, especially those with high rates of obesity and diabetes. They are interested in giving back to their communities and have an understanding of urban health issues, working with diverse populations, and community outreach. Location: City-wide Key Responsibilities: Conduct group fitness classes (safe/fun). Report attendance weekly. Time Commitment: One hour, once a week. For a least 6 months. Certification or Education Requirements: Currently certified in fitness instruction by one or more of the following: ACE, ACSM, AFAA, NASM or any other accredited health and fitness certifying organization (i.e. Zumba, Pilates, Yoga, PiYo...) A baccalaureate degree from an accredited college or university in the health field such as human performance, sports medicine, exercise physiology, kinesiology or other health related concentrations are a plus. Required skills: Effective communication, fitness leadership, group instruction. Benefits: Enthusiastic and supportive atmosphere. Opportunity to give back to the community. Applicable Skills: Fitness, Sports Medicine, exercise, physiology, public health
10029.title: Certified Group Fitness Instructor for Shape Up NYC!

10029.description: El Taller is looking for volunteers to help out during our concerts and events. Tasks include collecting money at the door, letting people into the space, setting up chairs, taking donations at the wine bar, and cleaning up after the show. Meet interesting people and hear world-class live music for free!
10029.title: Concerts and Special Events at El Taller Latino Americano

10029.description: As we are currently facing very difficult budget cuts in New York State, our Food Pantry which serves East Harlem children and families is experiencing a dramatic reduction of donations. Our shelves are barely stocked. If you work for an organization that might be interested in hosting a Food Drive, please be in touch (646) 672-0434. Canned food, dry goods, and other practical foodstuffs are most needed. We can pick up at any site in New York City. Thank you for remembering our most vulnerable New Yorkers!!
10029.title: Can Your Organization host a Food Drive for our Food Pantry?

10029.description: URGENT NEED! Help us help the neediest students in New York City! ! We need caring, committed after school Tutors for our After School Tutoring Program. WE HAVE A WAITING LIST FOR CHILDREN FOR THIS PROGRAM, AS WE NEED VOLUNTEER TUTORS. Times needed: MONDAYS FROM 3:30 - 4:30 and 4:45 - 5:45 Wednesdays from 4:45 - 5:45 You will tutor one-on-one a child in grades K- 3 who struggles with reading and writing at grade level. Most of the children are children of immigrants and English is not spoken at home, so they struggle with English reading and writing at school. Tutoring begins mid October and continues through the spring sememster (until June 2017). Please help an East Harlem child! Tutoring makes all the difference for our children -- the difference between success and failure in school. If you would like to volunteer, please email an inquiry email with your resume to tgough@lsafhs.org
10029.title: URGENT!!  We Need Tutors - for Mondays, Wednesdays, for East Harlem Children!

10029.description: Do you work for a company that wants to assist underpriviliged children in New York City? Help us give healthy sancks to children in our Summer Reading and Math Academy: https://yougivegoods.com/lsa-healthysnackdrive Othere ways your company can help: 1) Your company can host a Toy or Book Drive for children in our programs. We are always in need for educational toys and books for children ages 0 - 12. (we can pick up donations as needed). Our Holiday Program for Families is always in need of new clothing/toys/books for children, especially as gifts for the holidays. 2) Your company can host a Party for children at your office - a great \"team building\" activity for your company and a great way for our children to enjoy an outing and interaction with caring adults. Activities typically include an activity, i.e. art or craft making, and treats (food/snacks). Activity can also be at a local restaurant, or an educational or cultural venue. 3) Your company can work with children at our center for a \"team building\" activity - for example, a 1.5 hour arts and crafts activity or outdoor sports activity are just a couple of ways your group can connect with East Harlem children in our programs. Contact the Volunteer Director for more information. 3) Your company can sponsor a summer trip for our children (to NY state parks, beaches, the Bronx zoo, etc.). For more information about how your company can participate in an activity with our East Harlem children, please contact the Volunteer Director at LSA Family Health Service (646) 672-0434 or email at tgough@lsafhs.org.
10029.title: Corporate Sponsorship Needed! Please Support our Summer Program's Healthy Snack Drive!

10029.description: If you like thrift shops, you'll love the Sharing Place thrift shop. The Sharing Place offers high quality goods at very low prices for members of the East Harlem community. We need help in sorting and pricing clothes, helping customers, helping to decorate/set up store. We also need a volunteer who can assist with administrative tasks; i.e. help with thank you letters to donors, or helping to organize special store sales for the community.
10029.title: Thrift Shop Helpers Needed!

10026.description: Harlem Wellness Center is seeking an energetic, self starter to help create and lead our volunteer department. Our model of leadership is power to and power with. If you are great at building and inspiring a team we'd love to meet you. The Volunteer Director role includes recruitment of talented volunteers, matching expertise to assignments, project management and retention of volunteers.
10026.title: Leader

10027.description: National College Decision Day, generally acknowledged on May 1st, is an annual event that grants high school seniors an opportunity to announce their college selections. On this day, seniors publicly commit to their college choices and celebrate the efforts of their arduous college admissions process. The New York Consortium wants to mark this occasion by hosting the foremost National College Decision Day event in New York City. This year, we will be celebrating 250 high school seniors from 25 college access organizations across the City announcing aloud their college choices. Photography Time: Thursday, May 11, 2017, 3:30 PM - 7:30 PM Photography Purpose : HEAF 5th Annual College Decision Day Location: The Apollo Theater- 253 W 125th St, New York, NY 10027 How to Apply: Please send a brief overview of your interest along with your resume to volunteer@heaf.org
10027.title: College Decision Day Photographer

10027.description: Volunteer with Behind the Book (www.behindthebook.org), a non-profit literacy organization that inspires New York City public school students to love reading. Through our innovative programs, accomplished authors lead workshops in high-needs pre-K-12 classrooms, where they guide students in creating their own writing and art projects based on the theme of the author's book. No experience or training is necessary to work with students. As a writing, research or art coach, you'll engage them and encourage their progress on a project. This workshop needs your support at an elementary school in Harlem, NYC. To sign up, please contact volunteer@behindthebook.org with the program code: Program 15412KM-J Date: Tuesday, May 16th, 2017 Time: 9:30 - 10:45 AM Volunteer Role: Writing Coach Overview: This combined first- and second-grade class learned about various worms, their anatomy, and their role in helping fertilize soil with We Dig Worms! by Kevin McCloskey. Writing coaches will guide students in reaching final drafts of their reports on a \"garden helper\" of their choice. On May 9th, 9:30 - 10:45 AM, students will work with research coaches to find facts about a bee, butterfly, ladybug or worm (you can sign up for one or both dates). To find other Behind the Book programs around the city, visit http://www.behindthebook.org/current-volunteer-opportunities/ To join our team and receive announcements of new volunteer opportunities as they're posted, please complete our brief questionnaire at http://www.behindthebook.org/join-us/volunteer/
10027.title: Inspire Harlem, NYC public school students to love reading

10027.description: The Harlem Arts Festival (HAF) is proud to announce its 6th annual festival, a weekend-long party full of free music, dance, theater, and visual art, taking place June 23-25 in Marcus Garvey Park! The Festival is the centerpiece of HAF's ongoing programming that celebrates and promotes Harlem’s vibrant cultural landscape and contemporary artistry. At last year's festival, more than 6,000 attendees enjoyed performances by more than 40 artists over two days on two different stages. We're expecting an even larger crowd for this year's festival, and that is why we need you more than ever! Volunteers are the key to making the Festival happen, and we've got jobs for everyone. You can help out for one 6 hour shift, a whole day, or even the whole weekend. Below is a list of the positions we need to fill; you can find longer descriptions and more information at http://www.harlemartsfestival.com/volunteer/ Stage Crew Greeters & Street Teams Info Booth Attendants Kids Corner Attendants Builders/Runners Medical Assitants Merchandise Sales Artist Liaison Whether you've volunteered with HAF before or this is your first time, we look forward to working with you on this incredible event that brings artists across Harlem together to celebrate the culture of one of the most diverse neighborhoods in New York City.
10027.title: Volunteer with the Harlem Arts Festival #HAF2017!

10027.description: HIGH SCHOOL STUDENT SEMINARS 1. Plan seminars: identify & contact presenters 2. Manage and collect sign-in sheets 3. Contact students: reminders and follow-up on absences and lateness 4. Plan and coordinate activities/outings HIGH SCHOOL STUDENT COMMUNITY SERVICE 1. Identify and develop new placements 2. Assist students with placements 3. Monitor placements 4. Coordinate the final presentations event FUNDRAISING 1. Develop and monitor fundraising plan with students 2. Work with Parents on fundraising 3. Report to fundraising committee (board) 4. Work on the annual benefit MARKETING, PUBLICITY AND OUTREACH 1. Facilitate production of a monthly newsletter 2. Obtain articles from volunteers and Fellows, produce newsletter in Constant Contact 3. Manage the newsletter mailing list SOCIAL MEDIA 1. Maintain IYLI activity in Twitter and Facebook 2. Work with IYLI Fellows who are doing a CSDP to maintain IYLI activity in Twitter and Facebook 3.Research organizations for student recruitment, to market IYLI programs, develop partnerships, sponsorships for Fellow scholarships 4. Develop materials to support marketing and outreach ADMINISTRATION 1. Financial record keeping 2. Filing 3. Scanning paper records to make electronic copies
10027.title: Help Youth Become Global Citizens

10027.description: The Harlem Educational Activities Fund, Inc. (HEAF) is a comprehensive education and youth developmentorganization that works to help motivated, underserved students develop the intellectual curiosity, academicability, social values, and personal resiliency they need to ensure success in school, career, and life. OurOnward College Support Program provides first-generation college students with the continuing social,emotional, career and community support they need to make the transition to college and to complete their undergraduate studies. The Onward College Success Coaches play a vital role in supporting our students identify and accomplish their collegiate goals. Responsibilities: Coach one high school senior (12th grader) through the college application process Assist students with setting and accomplishing collegiate goals Guide students through how to determine their \"best fit\" college or university Coach students in creating a college list that includes 3 reach, 4 target, and 3 safety colleges Help to identify resources and opportunities that allow students to prepare effectively for standardized exams including, the SAT and ACT Assist students in proofreading, editing, and revising their personal statements and essays Assist students in understanding and applying for federal aid including the FAFSA Coach students in exploring and understanding the social and emotional aspects of going away Build trust and establish a genuine relationship with students through frequent communication and several in-person meetings/activities Submit monthly activity reports to the Manager of Onward Time Commitment: 1 yr. commitment (2nd & 3rd yr. coaching opportunities available given satisfactory performance),beginning in May 2017 Attend a 2 hour orientation and training Communicate with student via telephone, text message, social media, and/or email weekly to assess student progress, continue building a strong relationship, and to problem solve Meet 1-1 with student at least once each month either on or off-site Help to support other success coaches through collaboration and communication via an online success coach forum Attend an initial orientation and training session - additional training sessions maybe required Attend program events, supervision meetings, and program recognition events Requirements: Be at least 21 years of age or older Reside or work in the NYC Metropolitan Area Hold a Bachelors Degree from an accredited college or university Be able to commit to 1 year of college success coaching Be willing to adhere to program policies and procedures Be willing to complete the application and screening process including a background check Be willing to communicate regularly with Onward staff and take constructive feedback We strongly encourage professionals who have particular field experience in education, academic advising, counseling, and or college admissions to apply! NOTE: This is an unpaid volunteer opportunity. If you are interested in applying, please contact Kelli Goodman, Manager of Volunteer Initiatives at kgoodman@heaf.org or 212-663-9732 ext. 313 for an application
10027.title: Onward College Success Coach (Unpaid Volunteer Position)

10027.description: ATTENTION PHOTOGRAPHERS Start Small Think Big is seeking enthusiastic and reliable photographers who are interested in volunteering their skills to help underserved small business entrepreneurs build and sustain their thriving businesses. You must have a passion for all aspects of photography, but an individual with a specific interest in food and product photography would be ideal. Contact Mabell Fernandez, Market Access Program Director for further details: mabell@startsmallthinkbig.org or visit bit.ly/startsmallthinkbig for this and other volunteer opportunities.
10027.title: Photographer for small businesses

10027.description: Position: The Admissions Intern is a part-time position handling tasks associated with recruiting, screening and admitting students into the HEAF program for our two program sites. Intern will be trained and placed at program headquarters in Manhattan, and report to HEAF’s Manager of Admissions & Community Relations. Intern’s weekly hours range from 10-15 hours per week depending on designated weekly work levels. Program & Administrative Duties Include: Orient, and support prospective students participating in the Admissions process. Help plan Admissions special events (e.g. Open Houses, Appreciation Events, and Special Tours). Collect and maintain student information, including application and other supplemental materials (such as report cards). Prepare written weekly Admissions status reports on received applications, interviewed candidates and accepted students. Design and update Admissions collateral. Use technology (including, but not limited to, email, databases) as means of engaging in communications with prospective families and HEAF staff. Serve as a flexible team member and provide perform other related tasks as deemed necessary by the organization. Qualifications College students in education, social work or related field encouraged to apply. High School diploma and two additional years of volunteer or youth management experience may be considered. Motivated self-starter and team player with strong interpersonal and communication skills, both oral and written, and a positive attitude. Ability to set clear goals and follow through with flexible and creative problem solving. Conceptual ability for the larger perspective with a strong attention to detail and ability to multitask. Working knowledge of computer and internet-based programs for use in communication, data entry and research. (e.g. using Microsoft Software (Word, Excel, and PowerPoint)). Compensation and Benefits This position is unpaid
10027.title: Admissions Volunteer Intern

10027.description: Current Projects Assist in Finance Department Enter incoming invoices into QuickBooks Prepare monthly and weekly reports Assist in managing accounting and record keeping systems in QuickBooks Assist in Reconciliation of business account with American Express on a monthly basis. Assist in Generating, monitoring, and reviewing financial transactions ensuring accuracy and appropriateness. These include Check requests (payments of all vendor invoices), Petty Cash, and Reimbursements. Assist with weekly bank deposits Required Skills 4 year accounting Degree Microsoft Excel Volunteer Benefits Gain & expand new skills. Support HEAF staff in their work. Learn about the internal processes of a non-profit. Receive academic credit if applicable. Expand your professional network. Be part of a lively, dedicated, caring, and passionate team. Location: HEAF’s offices (2090 7 th Avenue, 10 th Floor, New York NY 10027) Supervising Staff: Deirdre Bennett & Shatia Mckinnon (Finance & Administration Team) Time Commitment: (24 hours per week) Documents Necessary Online volunteer application: ______ Background check: _______ Confidentiality form: ______
10027.title: Finance Volunteer

10027.description: The Food Pantry Volunteer will help sort food products for assembling; preparing food packages according to a pre-selected menus. Assist in the delivery of food packages in the seniors building. This project is in the Manhattan and Brooklyn area.
10027.title: Food Pantry Volunteer

10027.description: Researchers at Teachers College, Columbia University are seeking adolescents and young adults (ages 12-19 years) to participate in a study aimed at understanding different patterns of thoughts and feelings experienced throughout this developmental period. We are recruiting adolescents with diverse backgrounds, some who have been depressed or had thoughts of hurting themselves, and some who have never had these thoughts. Adolescent participation involves one laboratory visit involving computer tasks, interviews, and a self-report packet Eligible participants will be compensated at the end of the visit Parent consent is required for adolescents under 18 years If interested, please call 212-678-7487 or email lcds@tc.columbia.edu with your child to see if he/she qualifies for participation. Adolescents under 18 years must complete this phone screen in the presence of a parent.
10027.title: Tweens and Teens for Well-Being Study

10027.description: Do you have a love for Science and engaging in hands-on science activities with students? Do you enjoy speaking with students about what you do? Then join us at least once, or frequent our STEM Kids NYC Science Cafe that will open on alternate Fridays throughout the year. In this cafe, which will be run mostly by the students, you'll have the opportunity to share your love for Science and engage with them on a hands-on activity that supports what you do for a living, or some other area in Science you have a penchant for. Don't worry about teaching! You'll receive all the support you need from us who will develop the lessson plan around your expertise, and be there with you to help facilitate the sessions. Your presence and contribution of mastery is invaluable in helping students tap into their natural ability for Science, as well as enable them to develop their own identify around being a Scientist themselves. Your time commitment would be for a 3 hour segment for one or multiple Fridays. It's your choice. Thank you in advance for your consideration!
10027.title: Calling All Scientists! Join Our Student Science Cafe!

10027.description: The Borgen Project is an innovative, national campaign that is working to make poverty a focus of U.S. foreign policy. This is a part-time 14-hours per week, unpaid telecommuting internship. The internship is 4-months and responsible for leading public and political outreach in the state and district assigned to. Key Responsibilities: - Must be available Mondays 4:30-6:00 PM PST for The Borgen Project’s national conference call. - Meet with members of Congress and/or Congressional staffers in your State and District. - Represent The Borgen Project at various business, political and community events. - Assist with fundraising. Create a personal fundraising campaign and meet targets. - Mobilize individuals to contact their members of Congress in support of key poverty-reduction legislation. - As needed, speak to groups, classes and organizations. - Write letters of support for key programs to political leaders, media and other groups. Qualifications: - Outstanding writing skills. - Self-starter who can produce great results with limited supervision. - Strong oral communication skills and ability to lead meetings and give speeches.
10027.title: Political Affairs Internship

10027.description: The Borgen Project is an innovative, national campaign that is working to make poverty a focus of U.S. foreign policy. This is a 12-week, part-time, unpaid internship. The selected candidate will be able to work from home and set their own schedule, but must meet weekly deadlines. Articles submitted will appear on BORGEN Magazine or The Borgen Project Blog. Key Responsibilities: - Interview sources and research topics in-depth. - Write 2 well-researched articles per week. - Communicate with editors and supervisors. - Assist with fundraising. Create a personal fundraising campaign and meet targets. - Attend national conference call and/or training every Monday at 4 - 5:30 PM PST. Qualifications: Strong journalism writing skills. Must be able to work independently and meet deadlines with very little supervision. Experience writing for newspapers is helpful, but not required.
10027.title: Journalism Internship

10027.description: The Borgen Project is an innovative, national campaign that is working to make poverty a focus of U.S. foreign policy. This is a 12-week, part-time, unpaid internship. The selected candidate will be able to work from home and pick their own schedule, but must meet weekly deadlines. Articles submitted will appear on BORGEN Magazine or The Borgen Project Blog. Key Responsibilities: - Write 2 articles per week. - Research topics. - Assist with advocacy efforts. - Assist with fundraising. Create a personal fundraising campaign and meet targets. - Attend national conference call and/or training every Monday at 4 - 5:30 PM PST. Qualifications: Strong research and writing skills. Must be able to work independently and meet deadlines with very little supervision. Experience writing SEO friendly content is helpful, but not required.
10027.title: Writer Internship

10027.description: The Borgen Project is an innovative, national campaign that works with U.S. leaders to improve their response to the global poverty crisis. The Borgen Project is hiring an HR Intern who will work remotely. This human resources role will focus on national recruitment and updating job postings. Key Responsibilities: - Update job postings (80% of internship). - Inform groups and classes of openings. - Take on various tasks as needed. - Everyone who is part of the organization assists the team with fundraising, 25-hours of this position is dedicated to creating and implementing a personal fundraising campaign. - Assist with advocacy efforts. Details: This is an unpaid internship, although college credit is available. The HR internship is 16-hours per week for 12-weeks. Must meet weekly deadlines and be available Monday evenings 5-6PM PST for meetings and national conference calls.
10027.title: HR Internship

10027.description: The Borgen Project is an innovative, national campaign that works with U.S. leaders to improve their response to the global poverty crisis. The Borgen Project is hiring a Public Relations/Marketing Intern who will work remotely. This public relations intern will be involved in a variety of aspects of marketing and communications. Key Responsibilities: - Create a branding campaign. - Conduct an informal focus group and gather feedback for market research. - Pitch story ideas to print, broadcast and digital media. - Create and implement a fundraising strategy. - Plan, market and present at an informational meeting. - Utilize social media and develop strategies for web-based messaging. - Assist with The Borgen Project's advocacy efforts. - Take on assignments as needed. Details: This is an unpaid internship, although college credit is available. The internship is 16-hours per week for 12-weeks. Must meet weekly deadlines and be available the first Monday evening of the month, at 5pm PST for meetings.
10027.title: Public Relations/Marketing Internship

10027.description: The Borgen Project is an innovative, national campaign that works with U.S. leaders to improve their response to the global poverty crisis. You don’t need to be a lobbyist to help influence foreign policy. As a Regional Director, you’ll serve as a Borgen Project Ambassador in your city - mobilizing your friends, family and colleagues to contact Congress in support of key poverty reduction legislation. This is an unpaid, volunteer position. Key Responsibilities: - Attend one (30-60 minute) national conference call per month: 5PM PDT 6PM MDT 7PM CDT 8PM EDT - Meet with local congressional leaders and lobby for legislation that improves living conditions for the world’s poor. - Mobilize people in your community to contact their congressional leaders to support poverty reduction legislation. - Manage and implement fundraising campaigns. - Build a network of people engaged in the cause. - Serve as The Borgen Project’s ambassador in your city. Qualifications: - Basic understanding of U.S. Politics and international development. - Highly organized with the ability to prioritize multiple functions and tasks while managing their work time efficiently. - Strong team player that loves to bring new ideas to the table. - Ability to demonstrate frequent independent judgment with decisiveness. - Excellent overall communication skills: oral, written, presentation.
10027.title: Regional Director

10027.description: The Borgen Project is an innovative, national campaign that works with U.S. leaders to improve their response to the global poverty crisis. This is a great entry-level volunteer position for someone looking to be part of The Borgen Project. Advocates can operate from anywhere in the U.S. This is an unpaid, volunteer position. Key Responsibilities: - Attend one (30-60 minute) national conference call per month: 5PM PDT 6PM MDT 7PM CDT 8PM EDT - Serve as an ambassador for the world’s poor. Build awareness of the issues and ways people can help. - Manage and implement fundraising campaigns. - Represent The Borgen Project in your city - attend events and engage people in the cause. - Contact congressional leaders in support of key poverty-reduction programs. Qualifications: - Excellent overall communication skills: oral, written, presentation. - Ability to self-manage and prioritize assignments.
10027.title: Advocate

10027.description: The Jewish Board's Harlem Community Residence provides transitional living studio apartments and mental health services for adults with mental illness. As a Activity Specialist at our Harlem Community Residence, you can share your passions, hobbies with our residence. We are currently looking for someone to lead a writing group, a music group, and a board games group. Other ideas include a cooking group in which residents can learn about healthy foods and try out new recipes, or a current events group in which everyone gathers with a coffee and a newspaper and talks about what is happening around the world.
10027.title: Activity Specialist - Manhattan (Harlem)
10027.org: Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services

10027.description: The Jewish Board's Harlem Community Residence provides transitional living studio apartments and mental health services for adults with mental illness. As a fitness instructor, you can lead classes such as yoga, zumba, or a walking group. Experience leading fitness classes is a plus.
10027.title: Fitness Instructor - Manhattan (Harlem)
10027.org: Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services

10027.description: Lead three day, life changing experiential workshops in New York State prisons, schools and communities through exercises in affirmation, communication, cooperation, community building and creative conflict transformation. AVP is based on the understanding that every person is valuable and that wisdom lies within the group. Facilitators do not have answers. We are all learning together. Facilitators create a safe place for participants to discover our own truths. Key responsibilities: Facilitate on-team three day workshops Monitor group process and respond to keep building community and provide exercises and material at an engaging level Work collaboratively with a team to plan and lead a meaningful and dynamic workshop Report on the work done to AVP New York
10027.title: Alternatives to Violence Project Workshop Facilitator

10027.description: Come contribute your accounting and bookkeeping expertise to an up and coming startup nonprofit that provides STEM programs to underrepresented students in the New York City and Northern New Jersey communities. We launched in August 2015, and received our tax exempt status in November 2015. We have already received one grant and will be pursuing additoinal grant funding. We have begun to receive income from schools and agencies, so we'll need to work fast to stay on top of the books! In addition, there was income realized in 2015, so we'll need to generate financials and tax prep files to send to the IRS before the deadline. We are looking for someone to help prepare payroll for one employee. What we'll really need is for the accounting partner to advise on how to submit payroll taxes. Once that is done, we can do this part in house on a monthly/quarterly basis. We will need our partner to produce financial statements and ensure that accounting entries for our very minimal transactions are booked to the right chart of accounts. Further, our partner will reconcile the company's bank statements and advise us how to treat our income, be it from donations, grants, or receipts from schools and agencies. Lastly, we are looking for our partner to, well, partner with us by sharing with the Executive Director on any anomalies with the accounting processes that may occur throughout the month and providing any analysis of the transactions that are warranted.
10027.title: Bookkeeper Needed

10027.description: HEAF is seeking for educated professionals who are willing to commit to working with one of our students throughout their senior year of high school. The selected coaches will help guide and assist students throughout the college application and admission process. Mentors have the opportunity to truly affect the life of a young, college-bound student through this exciting and challenging time. Academic Coach Responsibilities: Academic assistance in core subjects (Math, English, Science, AP, SAT Test Prep, Social Studies) Assist students with homework, projects, and test preparation Time Commitment: At least one semester Once a week minimum, 4:00 - 6:30pm How to Apply: Please fill out our volunteer form ( http://bit.ly/1RUbSM0) and send an email of interest to volunteer@heaf.org. The volunteer coordinator will get in touch with you.
10027.title: High School Academic Coach/Tutor

10027.description: Do you enjoy the written word? Are you familiar with proper form and function in a poem? Do you have a passion for putting pen to paper, or fingers pressed to keyboard, expressing your thoughts and ideas through short stories? Have you wanted to read your work aloud and inspire others to do the same? If so, our small creative writing workshop is the perfect volunteer position for you. In an effort to bring freeform thoughts, hopes, dreams and ideas to the written word, we encourage our clients and residents to participate in various writing exercises, possibly reading their work aloud, sharing their ideas with one another. And we can use your skill; either by helping them put their words to paper, reading their aloud for them and more.
10027.title: Do you enjoy creative writing?  Want to share your passion?

10024.description: Since 2001 DOROT’s prestigious Summer Teen Internship Program has been inspiring high school students to become leaders and give back to the community. Volunteer with a diverse group of socially-conscious high school students to help local seniors connect. The internship is designed to provide students with a minimum of 92 hours of community service. * Documentary Filmaking - Session I * Intergenerational Theater - Session II * Deliver meals and birthday cakes * Teach computer skills * Cook and dine with seniors * Plan intergenerational trips to local museums * 104 hours of community service Session 1: June 26 - July 20 (exceptions made for regents exams) Session 2: July 24 - August 17 Apply here: www.dorotusa.org/teenapp Watch a Day in the Life of a DOROT Teen Intern: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jeXyE2YSHCM ''It’s an incredibly fulfilling experience to reach out to the seniors in the community and help them with whatever they need assistance with. It's also an added benefit that, as teen interns, we can build relationships with other teens who love the same service work. -Maude, Summer Teen Intern The DOROT Summer Teen Internship Program is jointly funded by UJA-Federation of New York and the Jim Joseph Foundation. The Jewish Education Project serves as lead operator of the Initiative.
10024.title: Summer Teen Internship Program 2017

10024.description: Volunteer tutors needed for low income students for summer session from 7/5/17-8/18/17. You will be matched one-to-one for just two hours per week. Students range in age from 7-18. There are no weekend hours available.
10024.title: Help a Child!  Be a Summer Volunteer Tutor

10024.description: Please join us for a special intergenerational reading adventure for 2nd and 3rd graders and older adults. The program is ideal for youth who need extra encouragement to reach for a book and spend time discussing books. Nurture your child’s natural love of reading and chatting through a variety of fun and creative intergenerational activities. The group will read aloud a few books over the course of 14 sessions and discuss the major themes of the books respecting other’s differences and the value of kindness. Great food and art activities will follow. 2017 Dates: February 1 - orientation (for youth only) February 8, 15 March 1, 8, 15, 22 April 5, 19, 26 May 3, 10, 17, 24 Register online starting December 12. Only 12 spaces are available for youth. Parents need a pre-phone interview. For more information, please contact Shelley Levine at slevine@dorotusa.org. Please note: This program is only for students in 2nd and 3rd grade. We are not in need of teen or adult volunteers to assist in the program.
10024.title: Intergenerational Reading Adventure for 2nd and 3rd Grade Students

10024.description: Intergenerational Chess at DOROT Share your love of the game and bring a smile to a senior. \"One of the best things about playing chess with Mr. B is how excited we are to see each other.\" -Zach, age 13 Winter/Spring: Jan. 30-May 15 from 4:00-5:30pm Students and DOROT Seniors will get to know each other and play chess together. Refreshments will be served. Free. Requirements: for 6th - 12th grade students must commit to all sessions understand the game of chess understand the different chess pieces and how to move them Intergenerational Chess at DOROT is sponsored by the Targoff family and friends
10024.title: Intergenerational Chess - Youth Needed to Play Chess with Seniors

10024.description: Goddard Riverside's Phelps House is seeking a Spanish speaking tutor to help a 73 year old older adult learn how to read. This individual can write and sign her own name, but does not know how to read or write. She is interested in learning the alphabet. She only speaks Spanish. Goddard Riverside serves some 17,000 people each year through 26 programs on the Upper West Side and throughout Manhattan. We work every day for a fair and just society where all people have the opportunity to make choices that lead to better lives for themselves and their families. If you are interested in volunteering, please contact Brianne Kilpatrick at BKilpatrick@goddard.org
10024.title: Spanish Speaking Tutor Needed for Older Adult

10024.description: Goddard Riverside is seeking a Horticulturist volunteer to work with our Older Adult population to help beautify our Senior Center garden. Dates and time are flexible between Monday - Friday 9-5. Goddard Riverside serves some 17,000 people each year through 26 programs on the Upper West Side and throughout Manhattan. We work every day for a fair and just society where all people have the opportunity to make choices that lead to better lives for themselves and their families. If you are interested, please contact Brianne Kilpatrick at BKilpatrick@goddard.org
10024.title: Horticulturist Needed

10024.description: Goddard Riverside is seeking a qualified individual to help with answering a switch board and helping out with front desk work - stamping mail, distributing mail and filing. This volunteer position is located in our Senior Center at 88th and Columbus Avenue. We are looking for someone who can volunteer with us Monday-Friday 9-5. It is a plus if you speak Spanish or another language. Goddard Riverside serves some 17,000 people each year through 26 programs on the Upper West Side and throughout Manhattan. We work every day for a fair and just society where all people have the opportunity to make choices that lead to better lives for themselves and their families. Interested individuals should send resume with cover letter to Brianne Kilpatrick at BKilpatrick@goddard.org.
10024.title: Clerical Help Needed

10024.description: \"We must love each other and support each other\" City Solidarity is an opportunity to do just this. Show love and care for our displaced neighbors and friends. Each Thursday evening, we will gather at different locations across NYC to spend time with and distribute items (food, clothing, toiletries, reading materials, blankets, and etc.) to homeless individuals. We need volunteers to help us organize materials, transport materials, and/or distribute materials on this day. We also need individuals to help us identify areas with high populations of displaced individuals in need. Weekly commitments are not necessary, and at most you will give two hours of your day to this project.
10024.title: City Solidarity- give love and aid to NYC homeless

10024.description: Volunteer as an EMT or non-medical provider with CPMU! http://www.cpmu.com/index.php/join-cpmu/
10024.title: Volunteer with the Central Park Medical Unit!

10024.description: From a teen who visited a DOROT Senior: I LOVED THIS VISIT SO MUCH!!! It was really heartwarming and gratifying to see how elated Angie was after she opened the gifts that were in the birthday package. It was so nice to see someone so happy by our visit and what we brought with us. I felt very at ease and it was great talking to her and seeing her reaction to the gifts. -Jessica, 10th grade Teens help alleviate loneliness and social isolation of DOROT's seniors through a variety of hands-on experiences in the community and onsite at DOROT. Teen Interns may: visit seniors in their home for companionship. teach seniors how to use a computer, iPad, iShuffle, and other types of technology. celebrate seniors’ birthdays. deliver meals to seniors. send birthday cards out to seniors. read to visually impaired seniors. shop and delivery groceries to seniors. play chess, cards, scrabble, and other games with seniors. assist with office work at DOROT. take part in a variety of other opportunities and experiences. Time Commitment: 1 day a week (Monday - Thursday) 2 hours a day (after school - no later than 4:00-6:00pm) 1 semester (minimum of 10 times at DOROT) Our Teen Internship has limited spots and is competitive, so teens must go through an application process. As a prospective intern, the first step is to fill out the interest form, then contact Shelley Levine at 917-441-5051 for a brief phone interview. We take great care to find teen interns who are committed, responsible, reliable, and enthusiastic about working with seniors. Eligibile teens are in 9th-12th grades.
10024.title: DOROT School Year TEEN Internship

10024.description: This opportunity is available every night! Excess bread can be combined with other ingredients to create meals to feed the hungry at a nearby food pantry rather than being thrown out. Help us walk with the food that would have been thrown away! We will get bags of bread and walk for this fifteen minute event, and will finish at the Rectory at the Holy Trinity Catholic Church at 213 W 82nd Street. Light Weight: the average total amount of food is 10 lbs. Sign up directly on our website: http://www.rescuingleftovercuisine.org/calendar
10024.title: Fight Food Waste & Feed the Hungry in Upper West Side 8:05PM-8:20PM

10024.description: Are you in-transition, new to being older, an empty nester, or retired? Looking for new experiences and new challenges at a new stage in life? Bring your knowledge, skills and patience that you’ve developed over the years to DOROT. You will also meet other volunteers that share similar interests. Knitting and Crocheting Afghans for Seniors Gather twice a month with other volunteers to knit or crochet Afghans that will be given to seniors at DOROT’s Homelessness Prevention and Aftercare Program. Wednesdays & Thursdays, 10:30 AM - 12:00 PM Thursday, October 20 Wednesday, November 2 Thursday, November 17 Wednesday, December 7 Thursday, December 22 2017 Wednesday, January 4 Thursday, January 19 Wednesday, February 1 Thursday, February 16 Wednesday, March 1 Thursday, March 16 Wednesday, April 5 Thursday, April 20 Wednesday, May 3 Thursday, May 18 Wednesday, June 7 Thursday, June 22 DOROT will provide some supplies, bringing your own is preferred. For more information and to register, please contact Rebecca Zinger, Coordinator of Adult Volunteer Services at rzinger@dorotusa.org or 917-441-5054.
10024.title: Knitting & Crocheting Afghans for Seniors- Upper West Side

10024.description: It’s an election year and it’s almost time to vote for our next President! The West Side Campaign Against Hunger will host a voter registration drive for the General Election beginning on Monday, August 1, 2016, through October 14, 2016. Help WSCAH customers register to vote by signing up for one of our voter registration trainings throughout June and July. You may choose from the following dates: Friday, July 15 at 2pm Friday, July 29 at 2pm If you’re outgoing and believe in the power of voting, this opportunity is for you! Bilingual in Spanish is helpful. Trained volunteers may choose to volunteer on any Monday and/or Wednesday between August 1 and October 14 for a 2 hour shift in the morning or afternoon. If you have any questions, please email Rashida Latef, Advocacy Coordinator, at rlatef@wscah.org or call 212-362-3662 ext 140.
10024.title: Be an advocate at the West Side Campaign Against Hunger!

10024.description: Help your community to stop food waste and fight hunger by bringing excess food to homeless shelters. You will be taking bags of excess food, which would have been thrown out by the restaurant, to the nearest homeless shelter. This is a great opportunity to gain community service experience while helping others at the same time!!!! Please sign up for events directly on our website: http://www.rescuingleftovercuisine.org/calendar

10024.description: Bring the knowledge, skills and patience you've developed to make a significant impact on the lives of older members of our community. Our DOROT seniors will benefit from your time and expertise. You will meet other volunteers and make new friends that share similar interests and are as passionate about volunteering as you. Volunteer Opportunities Inlcude: DOROT Buddies Intergenerational Programs Speaking Exchange Video Chat Services Groups Vist our website for more information: http://www.dorotusa.org/site/PageServer?pagename=vol_older_adult#.VkEWgLeFNdg
10024.title: Retired? Volunteer with DOROT and assist seniors.

10024.description: Customer and community volunteers are an integral part of what we do. We depend on volunteers for food pantry services, which creates a community of individuals helping others. Without volunteers, we would be unable to provide food and counseling services for as many people as we do. The majority of our volunteers are customers who choose to five back by donating hours of their time. We also have volunteers from the community, neighboring schools, corporations, foundations and religious congregations. Volunteers help bring in deliveries, stock shelves, bag bread, pack rice and beans, break down boxes, assist customers with their shoping, work the checkout area, and much more.
10024.title: Be a West Side Campaign Against Hunger Volunteer!

10024.description: Heat and serve dinner, socialize, and facilitate conversation at DOROT's transitional housing facility. Volunteers are needed Monday and Friday nights. DOROT social workers support you in your volunteer efforts. Interview, training, references, and background check are required responsible and mature volunteers 18
10024.title: Serve dinner &  socialize with seniors at DOROT's transitional housing

10024.description: Escort a senior to a cultural event such as a concert, movie, theater or museum. Interview, training, references and background check is required.
10024.title: Escort a senior to a cultural event

10024.description: Teach basic computer skills and internet navigation to a senior in their home. Lessons are 1-4 sessions, depending on the senior’s needs, for approximately one hour. Interview, training, references and background check is required.
10024.title: Teach computer skills to  elderly in Manhattan

10024.description: Make a friend for a lifetime! Visit a compatible senior, one-on-one, for conversation, companionship and to share mutual interests. These weekly 1 hour visits occur within the home of a senior residing on the East Side or Upper West side of Manhattan. You will be matched by a professional social worker to establish a meaningful and rewarding relationship. Interview, training, references, background check and year-long commitment required.
10024.title: Become a Friendly Visitor with a local senior

10024.description: Are your customer service skills 'up to snuff'? At the West Side Campaign Against Hunger, volunteers who fulfill the role of check-out help in the pantry assisting customers with their shopping. Training will be provided. Knowledge of Spanish, Cantonese, French, Urdu, or Russian is very helpful, but not neccessary. Volunteer Hours: Monday: 7 am to 7 pm Tuesday: delivery day, 7 am to 11 am Wednesday, Thursday and Friday: 7 am to 4 pm
10024.title: Bilingual Volunteers Needed!

10024.title: Help frail seniors with grocery shopping and errands in Manhattan

10025.description: The New Jewiish Home, Manhattan Division has a wide variety of opportunities for high school and college students to volunteer with over the summer vacation. Opportunities vary and we will try our best to meet your interest Opportunities include but not limited to: Recreation Assistant (Bingo, Games, Exercise, Arts & Crafts, Nail Spa) Pharamacy (selective, limited spots) Library Assistant (upkeep of shelving, assisting book selections, assisting computer users) Clerical/Office Assistant Please apply online at the following link: https://www.volgistics.com/ex/portal.dll/ap?AP=229551104 Please mention Volunteer Match & Summer Volunteering in your application If you have any questions - Please contact Jessica at JSinovoi@jewishhome.org
10025.title: Summer Volunteer at The New Jewish Home (HS & College students)
10025.org: The New Jewish Home, Manhattan Division

10025.description: Each year, on the longest *day, Care for the Homeless and our allies take a few hours to recognize the stories of our homeless and formerly homeless neighbors. The Summer Solstice Success Celebration is an observance developed by Care for the Homeless in New York City and first held in 2014 to both celebrate success in overcoming homelessness and as an effort to de-stigmatize and humanize people experiencing homelessness in New York City. *The actual solstice is on June 21st but, due to important advocacy work in Albany that date, we will celebrate a day later. We are recruiting volunteers to assist with various duties at this event, including food service, set-up, break-down, etc. Where: Broadway Presbyterian Church, 601 West 114th Street, NY, New York 10025 When: June 20th. Time TBD. Who: 10+ Superstar Volunteers If interested, please contact the Volunteer Coordinator at jriendeau@cfhnyc.org directly for more information.
10025.title: Help Us Recognize the Successes of Homeless Individuals At Our Annual Summer Solstice Celebration!

10025.description: BECOME A SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY, ENGINEERING and MATH (STEM) VOLUNTEER! Help middle school and high school students develop a passion for math and science by becoming a dedicated instructor, teaching assistant, or afterschool tutor. Whether you're great, good or fair at Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM), you can help make an impact on inner-city youth. Here's how: The Parris Foundation S.T.E.M.ulating Minds Weekend Enrichment Program has returned for the Spring 2017 session . The program began after a successful summer pilot in 2012, and our subsequent programs have grown to continue to serve middle school students and high school students . With the growing impact on the community, we need your support to continue to bring STEM to our middle school and high school youth throughout New York City . As we expand to more locations to serve more youth, there is a growing need for volunteers! Our ideal volunteer is enthusiastic about working with youth, can commit to multiple Saturdays, and possesses, at minimum, basic science and math skills. No previous education experience is required. Your passion for science and math coupled with a desire to help New York City youth realize their true potential is all that is required.
10025.title: Spring & Summer 2017 - S.T.E.M.ulating Minds Weekend Enrichment Program

10025.description: A Fair Shake for Youth, is a 7-year old nonprofit organization that uses the therapy dogs to help underserved NYC middle school aged youth build a foundation of empathy and self esteem. This social emotional learning program helps youth develope the skills and behaviors that foster more positive relationships and interactions. We are currently seeking additional Board members who would welcome the opportunity to work with others to help guide and support the organization as we continue to expand. Board experience is not required, but members must be interested in dogs and the challenges of kids growing up in poverty.
10025.title: Volunteer Board Member

10025.description: Would you like to make a difference with your dog? Disadvantaged children in New York City need help. Now you and your dog can help them. Become a volunteer team for A Fair Shake for Youth. A Fair Shake for Youth, Inc. is a non-profit that uses therapy dogs and AKC Canine Good Citizens to help middle-school aged youth in underserved communities build greater empathy and self-esteem, and reduce bullying. Dedicated volunteers and their dogs are at the heart of our program, power and success. Here's how it works: Three volunteer/dog teams each commit to a ten-week program Transportation is provided Teams work with the same group of 12 kids, becoming a consistent part of their school life Kids form a relationship with the volunteers and share the experience of making the dogs successful Volunteers experience a profound connection to the students - their struggles and success. Volunteers must be registered therapy dogs or AKC Canine Good Citizens.If your dog is not already one of these, training is available. We are looking for dogs that love people (especially children), are good with new situations, are resilient and well-mannered. For more information, please visit our website at www.afairshakeforyouth.org . If you and your dog would like to volunteer with us, please email volunteer@afairshakeforyouth.org
10025.title: Volunteer Dog Teams
10025.org: A Fair Shake for Youth, Inc.

10025.description: Walking Tour Guide Would you love to meet people from around the world? Do you love to show people around New York City? Everyday, we offer walking tours to see and experience New York City. This is the perfect opportunity to meet people from around the world. Daily Walking Tours meet at our beautiful Victorian mansion on the Upper West Side. From meeting location, we offer tours to Central Park, Brooklyn Bridge and all types of locations in the five boroughs of New York City.. Note: All volunteers must be punctual and able to commit to regular attendance over a 12-week term. Volunteers will: Give weekly or multi-weekly tours Foreign language ability is a plus but not a requirement Leaders can request tours for specific locations in the five boroughs Serve as representatives of New York to a global audience Help develop your public speaking and communication skills Receive volunteer hours that can be applied towards free hostel stays anywhere in our network of over 50 hostels in the USA Be eligible for volunteer trainings, appreciation events and more If you’re interested, please contact activities.newyork@hiusa.org for an application and more information or visit http://hinewyork.org/volunteer to apply. We’re looking for people who love to travel! HI New York is the largest nonprofit organization dedicated to youth travel in New York, and the largest hostel in North America.

10025.description: Volunteering your time to change the lives of adults with developmental disabilities. Sprout is a non-profit organization based in New York City focused on providing innovative programs for adults with developmental disabilities.With our network of resources and dedicated volunteers, which we call leaders, Sprout opens up fascinating new worlds to people with disabilities. Sprout's Overnight Vacations Program is looking for individuals who have the energy, motivation and desire to work with adults with developmental disabilities. What do Sprout leaders do? Sprout leaders' primary goal is to give adults with developmental disabilities the opportunity to experience and enjoy recreational, educational and leisure activities through overnight vacations. Leaders are responsible for the overall safety and enjoyment of their group, 24 hours a day, while on a Sprout trip. Duties include safety monitoring, personal hygiene assistance, providing physical and emotional support, activity planning, budgeting, logistics, and enhancing fun. The work is hard yet immensely rewarding as you develop leadership skills and gain insight into your own abilities. What type of training is provided? Leaders must complete a pre-service training, which provides the necessary procedures and tools to run a successful and enjoyable vacation. Leaders who are drivers receive extra training on how to safely drive our 15-passenger vans. In addition, all leaders receive a copy of Sprout's Leadership Handbook to help with policies and guidelines. What is the time commitment? Sprout vacations last 3 - 7 days depending on the time of year and destination of the trip. When a leader is selected for an overnight vacation, Sprout asks that the leader dedicate themselves to stay with their group throughout the entire duration of the vacation. Some leaders only choose to lead one trip a year while others spend several months with us leading up to 8 trips or more. Sprout strives to make our program flexible for our leaders based on the amount of time leaders can give. Do leaders have any free or personal time while on a trip? Sprout trips are working vacations for the leaders who choose to participate. Because Sprout leaders are responsible for their group 24 hours a day, there is no free or personal time allotted. In order to give our participants the opportunity to experience and enjoy a vacation, Sprout leaders must be available at all times to provide the support any one participant may need. What type of trips can Sprout leaders expect to join? A majority of Sprout trips take place within a day's drive of New York City. Destinations include Atlantic City, Amish Country, Boston, Lake George, Cleveland, Maine and Virginia Beach. Exotic trips like cruises, Hawaii, and Europe are presented to leaders who have demonstrated high levels of commitment, service hours and have gained positive feedback from participants and Sprout office staff. Are there any special skills or requirements? No special background or education is required to become a Sprout leader. We encourage people from all cultures and professions, and of all ethnic and educational backgrounds. Once accepted into the program, you will receive the necessary tools to sign up for outings and how to assist our participants. Requirements include: -21+ years old -Provide references -Participate in training session -Willingness to complete necessary background checks -Evaluate participants' behavior -Fluent English -Willing to drive a 15 passenger van -Love to travel & have fun! How do I apply? TO APPLY: http://gosprout.org/vacation-programs/volunteer/volunteer-application/
10025.title: Vacation Trip Leader
