10025.title: Overnight Volunteer

10025.description: Staff the Ansche Chesed shelter from 7pm to 9pm. Open doors, orient new guests, answer questions, monitor activities.
10025.title: Opening Volunteer

10025.description: Make a difference by becoming a Sprout Day Trip Leader! Are you passionate about working with people who have developmental disabilities? Are you looking for a fun, flexible opportunity where you can actually see the difference that you're making? If so, Sprout may be exactly what you're looking for! Sprout's NYC Program provides evening and weekend recreational activities for highly-social adults with mild-to-moderate developmental disabilities. These activities are all over the five boroughs of New York City and include sporting events, museums, art classes, festivals, dinners and more! Sprout Leaders provide supervision to our groups for 2-6 hour long excursions while encouraging positive socialization and having fun with them. Leaders also assist with some logistical elements of activities such as handling a small budget or directing a participant to the nearest subway station. Each month, Leaders are sent a calendar of events and can choose the activities they would like to lead. We only ask that Leaders follow through with the commitment they make to assist with those activities. NO special background or education is required to become a Sprout leader. We encourage people from all cultures and professions, and of all ethnic and educational backgrounds. Once accepted into the program, you will receive a training session which will provide the necessary tools to sign up for and lead future activities. *We encourage applicants with diverse experience-levels and backgrounds *Must be 21 years or older *Fluency in English required TO APPLY: h ttp: gosprout.org/vacation-programs/volunteer/ OR EMAIL: l eadership@gosprout.org
10025.title: NYC Day Trip Leader

10022.description: Cathedral High School (CHS) is a Catholic, college preparatory school located in the heart of Manhattan, which welcomes young women of all faiths and cultures. Since it opened its doors in 1905, Cathedral has been a place where young women feel at home and are encouraged to be strong, smart, independent women who can do anything they set their minds to. In 2012, Cathedral High School was ranked by The New York Observer as one of New York City’s top 160 schools and among the top 35 private high schools. Almost all of our students are daughters of immigrant working families. 645 young women representing 72 countries attend CHS. Many of our students come from families who earn at or below the federal poverty level (60% of students are eligible for free or reduced lunch). Over 82% of our girls are Hispanic or of African American descent. Through the decades, CHS has continued to enhance its academic curriculum and extra-curricular activities to ensure that students graduate equipped with the skills necessary to be successful in college and careers thereafter. CHS routinely graduates nearly 100% of its students - compared to a current graduation rate of 61.3% for NYC public schools - and assists students in securing tens of millions of dollars in college scholarships. CHS graduates have the skills to be competitive in the global workforce and a sense of obligation to others so that they give back to their New York City community. We are seeking Volunteer Board Members to help us fulfill this mission.
10022.title: Volunteer Board Member

10022.description: Since 1917, Catholic Charities has been supporting New Yorkers of all backgrounds and religions - those in need of food, shelter, foster care, day care, counseling, immigration assistance, services for the physically and mentally challenged, employment assistance, and more. Come volunteer with us! To see our new opporunities, visit www.catholiccharitiesnyvolunteer.org
10022.title: Teaching Assistants, Mentors, Visually Impaired, Refugees and more
10022.org: Catholic Charities, Archdiocese of New York

10022.description: One volunteer is needed to teach an intermediate English conversation class on site to a group of blind and visually impaired adult students to supplement their regular classes. Orientation to working with individuals with vision impairments and adapting materials into accessible formats will be provided. The volunteer will create and implement lessons, maintain student attendance and progress records, and submit documents as requested by the academic supervisor. Skills needed: * Master’s degree in TESOL or related field * Prior teaching experience with proven record of success * Ability to develop and implement lessons appropriate for target population * Prior experience in working with blind and visually impaired individuals helpful * Patience, flexibility, and a heart for working with individuals with disabilities * Accurate recordkeeping Commitment: * 2 hours per week: Mondays 11 am - 1 pm * 6 months, longer preferred
10022.title: ESOL Instructor for Guild for the Blind
10022.org: Catholic Charities, Archdiocese of New York

10022.description: Nonviolence International is a decentralized network of resource centers that researches and promotes nonviolent action and seeks to reduce the use of violence worldwide. We believe that every culture and religion can employ appropriate nonviolence methods for positive social change and international peace. Nonviolence International NY focuses on the United Nations, and on the community of New York City. We aim to share with the New York community the important things happening at the UN in our areas of work: Culture of Peace and Nonviolence, Disarmament, Palestine: Peace and Justice, UN Goals, UN-Civil Society Relations, Women's Issues. We are looking for a volunteer to produce photo and video content on a weekly basis while working closely with our social media team. We have our own basic equipment, but if you have your own tripod or lights, that is helpful but not at all required to be chosen for this position. The responsibilities will include vidoegraphy and photography of live events, people, and our work. Volunteers will also have the opportunity to propose ideas for content.
10022.title: Photography and Videography for NGO

10022.description: Nonviolence International is a decentralized network of resource centers that researches and promotes nonviolent action and seeks to reduce the use of violence worldwide. We believe that every culture and religion can employ appropriate nonviolence methods for positive social change and international peace. Nonviolence International NY focuses on the United Nations, and on the community of New York City. We aim to share with the New York community the important things happening at the UN in our areas of work: Culture of Peace and Nonviolence, Disarmament, Palestine: Peace and Justice, UN Goals, UN-Civil Society Relations, Women's Issues. We are looking for an intern to run our social media accounts and write original content for our organization. Interns will gain both the expeerience of social media marketing, and working at an NGO.
10022.title: Social Media and Content Management for NGO

10022.description: Assistance is needed in researching potential volunteer board members for the Catholic elementary schools of the Archdiocese of New York. Computer skills needed (web search, Excel) -- Flexible hours.
10022.title: Volunteer Board Member Recruitment Coordinator Needed

10022.description: Interested in serving as a high impact agent of change on a New York City nonprofit board? Contact BoardAssist. BoardAssist is the leading personalized board recruiting resource available to the tri-state nonprofit community. We offer New Yorkers who want to make a real change in the nonprofit world hundeds of board options and advice on selecting the right one for them. Our nonprofit clients range from start-up organizations to some of the most established names in the nonprofit community, and serve interest areas from arts and education to the environment and poverty relief. Though most BoardAssist clients are New York-based, they serve locally, nationally and internationally. BoardAssist has been responsible for bringing over $65 million into the nonprofit community through our board placements over the last 15 years. We are a nonprofit ourselves. Please send your resume or LinkedIn link when emailing BoardAssist at info@boardassist.org, or simply fill out our new Candidate Application We very much appreciate your interest in giving back! Most boards require board members to give at least $5000/year to their nonprofit.
10022.title: Join a NYC Board of Directors - BoardAssist has 100s of openings

10022.description: Interested in serving as a high impact agent of change on a New York City nonprofit board? Contact BoardAssist. 10022.description: We are working at the United Nations to strengthen the influence of civil society and the enforceability of international human rights and humanitarian law, as well as get the American public more involved with the work of the UN. This includes work with Agencies and NGO committees at the UN focused on NGO relations, women's issues, Palestine and disarmament, as well as the activist community in New York and across the USA.
10022.title: The United Nations:  This is Your World !!

10022.description: Serve as a consultant/mentor to an elementary school administrators in the planning and implementation of their development and marketing efforts. Volunteer positions available throughout the Archdiocese of New York to assist administrators with some of the following projects: *Organizing fundraising efforts *Running specific campaigns *Alumni outreach and solicitations *Developing school publicity materials (school brochures, special project brochures) *Exploring potential grant sources (writing for grants possible) *Organizing volunteers to staff events. * Assisting in long-range planning and goal setting. Please contact the danielle.forsythe@archny.org to participate.
10022.title: Development/Marketing Volunteer Consultants Needed

10022.description: Groups needed to help the schools of the Archdiocese of New York with various projects such as painting, moving, cleaning etc. Week-ends best. Manhattan, Bronx, Staten Island, Westchester, Putnam, Ulster, Orange, Rockland and Duchess county locations. Please contact the Office of Educational Development at (212) 371-1011 x.3359 or at eddev@adnyschools.org to participate.
10022.title: Fun Group Service Projects!

10022.title: Searching for Great School Advisory Board Members!

10023.description: The Volunteer Referral Center and Health Advocates for Older People invite you to an informational program designed for volunteers of ALL AGES Come listen to our panel of diverse volunteer experts; hear about a broad range of opportunities; talk with volunteer directors; and get ready to make a difference in the world of volunteering. RSVP: 212-889-4805 or sign-up at http://volunteer-referral.com/volunteering-is-ageless-may-18-2017/ Admission is FREE Light Refreshments Provided
10023.title: Volunteering is Ageless

10023.description: The volunteer will assist instructors in rehabilitation, pre-vocational and recreational programming for teenagers who are blind or visually impaired. They will be required to monitor the youth as they move between classes and provide support on field trips. This teaching assistant will primarily assist a student in the people mover - a light weight wheelchair - with transitioning between classes, organizing and the like. The ideal candidate will be male to assist with bathroom orientation. Duties and Responsibilities: * Comfortable pushing a people mover - a light wheelchair. * Escorting the student to classes, the restroom etc. * Assist with transfers to chair. * Assist instructors in classes such as cooking, physical education and art. * Guide students as needed to classes within the building or on field trips. * Assist instructors and student by bringing enthusiasm to groups. Qualifications: * Must have a positive helpful attitude that will allow this student to harness independence with the assistance of a travel guide. * Able to handle confidential information. * Able to arrive on time and be prepared daily. * Flexibility with task requests. * Interest in working with students with disabilities preferred. * Positive attitude and enthusiasm is a must! * Must be sighted guide trained. * Bilingual Spanish a plus! * Must be able to stand for periods of time if required. Details of the Opportunity: The volunteer will be instructed by each staff on how best to help the student participate in program activities. To volunteer, or for more information about this opportunity respond to this e-mail or call Rosie Lopez at (646) 874-8682. Please include a telephone number for follow up!
10023.title: Volunteer Needed Saturday With Teens in NYC!

10023.description: Hours and days are flexible and negotiable. Majority of the work can be done remotely but volunteer will occasionally need to meet in-person with Freedom Ladder team members in the New York area. Duties and Responsibilities Prepares work to be accomplished by gathering information and materials Plans concept by studying information and materials Illustrates concept by designing rough layout of art and copy regarding arrangement, size, type size and style, and related aesthetic concepts Obtains approval of concept by submitting rough layout for approval Prepares finished copy and art by operating typesetting, printing, and similar equipment; purchasing from vendors Prepares final layout by marking and pasting up finished copy and art Completes projects by coordinating with outside agencies, art services, printers, etc. Contributes to team effort by accomplishing related results as needed. Works in collaboration with the E-commerce Manager, Website Manager, Videographer/ Multimedia Manager and other staff to develop and implement strategic initiatives related to Freedom Ladder’s on-line presence If you have 5+ years of experience in graphic design, please send us your resume and portfolio to freedomladder@outlook.com . Include \"Graphic Designer\" in the e-mail subject.
10023.title: Graphic Designer

10023.description: This is a unique opportunity for a MBA or graduate student to work with the executive suite of a $1 billion not-for-profit vision and healthcare organization. The candidate will assist the executive team, including the CEO, President, CFO and other members of the executive team plot the path of the future for the organization. The ideal candidate should be interested in healthcare and/or health policy with a desire to improve (even disrupt) the healthcare system as it exists today. The candidate will be engaged in helping to create business models for numerous ancillary businesses that the executive team is evaluating, including potential mergers and acquisitions, strategic partnerships and organic growth. This candidate will report to the chief financial officer. Principle Duties and Responsibilities: The candidate will be required to: Create a business plan Create a financial model to support the business plan that evaluates various scenarios and Return on Investment Perform a competitive analysis to understand the macro-economic environment and local regional nuances Complete other assignments required by the leadership team. Qualifications: MBA, MPA or Master student studying Health Policy Candidate should have basic business skills to create a business plan and financial model Strong proficiency in Microsoft Word and Excel is required Must be passionate about Healthcare Details of the Opportunity : This opportunity requires availability two days per week, six hours per day. Preference will be given to students available two semesters. Business casual attire (no jeans, no sneakers) is required during the internship.
10023.title: Graduate Management Internship in NYC

10023.description: Freedom Ladder currently seeks experienced education leaders (retired teachers, school administrators, etc.) who possess extensive knowledge of the NYC education landscape. Workshop leaders will work collaboratively with the Education Director to identify schools to conduct Freedom Ladder workshop sessions.
10023.title: Workshop Leader

10023.description: The Harriet and Robert Heilbrunn School provides education and therapeutic services to children ages 5-21 in a safe, secure setting. The School strives to help children develop the skills to live as independently as possible, prepare for adulthood, and maximize their talents and abilities. DATE: As soon as possible TIME: A morning session would be preferred, but open to an afternoon session as well. LOCATION: The Harriet and Robert Heilbrunn School, 3rd Floor, 15 West 65th Street New York, NY 10023 PRINCIPAL DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES: Under the direction of the Principal, the Volunteer will: Provide a 1 or 2 hour introductory Sign Language Workshop for the Heilbrunn School staff. The Volunteer will teach the staff basic Sign Language. QUALIFICATIONS: Certification in Sign Language. DETAILS OF THE OPPORTUNITY: Presently, this is a one time opportunity and the attire is business casual. To express your interest in this opportunity, please reply to this email or contact me, Sharon Montrose, at (646) 874-8762. Please include a telephone number for follow up! ­
10023.title: Volunteer Sign Language Instructor in NYC

10023.description: NCJW NY is looking for a committee food pantry volunteer to assist with distributing groceries and moving light inventory for our Monday Food Pantry. Volunteers must be able to lift light boxes a short distance and provide good customer service. Spanish speakers are particularly needed! Our Monday Food Pantry provides a three-day emergency supply of both fresh produce and shelf-stable groceries to families in need, serving approximately 200 families each week. The Food Pantry runs from 9 am to 2 pm and volunteer shifts are flexible. Please contact NCJW NY if you are interested in this dynamic and rewarding volunteer opportunity!
10023.title: Food Pantry Volunteer
10023.org: National Council of Jewish Women NY Section

10023.description: Remaining in their own homes is critical for our seniors and you can help! Compassionate, detail-oriented volunteers, using their every-day life skills, are needed to visit seniors and help with the timely payment of monthly bills. All Boroughs - Manhattan (especially 10024, 10036, 10128, 10463 zip codes), Brooklyn, Queens, the Bronx and Staten Island. Clients make all their own financial decisions but need hands-on help with bill paying tasks such as reviewing mail, organizing bills, writing out checks for the client to sign, reconciling check register to bank statements. Volunteers are screened, fingerprinted, undergo background check and receive detailed procedural instruction and coaching. The commitment is for one year, one or two visits a month for approximately 2-6 hours per month. Please call 212-602-4195 or email: volunteerbpp@aging.nyc.gov. The Bill Payer program is operated by NYC Department for the Aging.
10023.title: HELP OUR SENIORS STAY INDEPENDENT - ALL BOROUGHS
10023.org: NYC Dept. for the Aging Bill Payer Program

10020.description: Have fun and make an impact at one of ten projects across New York City for The Jewish Board's Spring 2017 Month of Hope! For our Month of Hope event at The Jewish Board headquarters, you can support literacy and good health by creating Art Kits for some therapeutic fun and birthday baking kits for children in our Jewish Board shelters. Help make days a little brighter for our families! Tuesday, May 16 | Midtown Manhattan | 6:00pm - 8:00pm
10020.title: Month of Hope: Assemble Care Packages - Midtown Manhattan
10020.org: Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services

10020.description: The Jewish Board works one-on-one with companies, schools, religious institutions, alumni groups, and families to organize group volunteer opportunities in all five boroughs and Westchester. Past group volunteer opportunities have included hosting a career day, creating care packages, and throwing a book and crafting party. If your group has an activity in mind or talents/skills to share, we would be happy to speak with you. Our clients and residents can benefit from new exposures and activities. Group Volunteer Opportunities are typically a one-time commitment for several hours.
10020.title: Group Volunteer Opportunities- Various Locations
10020.org: Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services

10020.description: The Greenberg Manhattan West Counseling Center offers mental health services to children, teenagers and adults. Treatment includes assessment and short and long term psychotherapy using multiple and flexible treatment modalities including individual, couple family and group treatment as well as evidence based psychotherapies. As a Client Companion for Greenberg Manhattan West Counseling Center, you will be a friend to one of the clients using their mental health services. This client lives in Midtown, and is looking for a lively and active volunteer in their 40s or 50s to accompany her on walks, bike rides, visits to the park, and to live music performances.
10020.title: Client Companion - Manhattan (Midtown West)
10020.org: Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services

10020.description: You can make a BIG difference in the life of a child. Become a BIG Brother/BIG Sister with The Jewish Board. Help a child become happier, more fulfilled, and better able to face the challenges of childhood or adolescence. The Big Brother Big Sister Program (BBBS) matches volunteers with children, ages 7-16 years old, who could benefit from an additional positive role model in their lives, positively impacting the well-being of the child. These children come from single parent families, special family circumstances, and/or are receiving services from The Jewish Board. Volunteers must be 21 years or older, available to spend between once a week and once a month with the child and make a minimum of a year commitment. We create and support matches that are positive, safe, and well suited to your and the child’s needs. Our Bigs come from all different backgrounds, and so do our Littles. Our professional staff carefully screens Bigs and Littles to make the best match possible based on common interests, personalities and location. Your commitment has a powerful impact on the life of a child.
10020.title: Big Brother Big Sister Program
10020.org: Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services

10021.description: The Carter Burden Network is dedicated to supporting the efforts of older people to remain in their homes living independently, safely, and with dignity. Volunteers are an integral component of the Carter Burden Network's 40+ years of success. No matter your age, experience or schedule, CBN can accommodate your needs to ensure that you have a meaningful and effective volunteer experience. Meals-On-Wheels deliver thousands of meals a year to our homebound seniors. The Carter Burden Luncheon Club & Senior Program is looking for eager and passionate volunteers to deliver meals to our Upper East Side senior clients. It's a great opportunity to check up on the senior and converse with them. You're not just delivering a meal, but also a smile! Volunteer hours are from 10:30am to 12:30pm. We need volunteers for the following dates: May 4th, 5th 16th & 18th
10021.title: Meal Delivery to Homebound Seniors on May 4th, 5th 16th & 18th

10021.description: The Carter Burden Network (CBN) is dedicated to supporting the efforts of older people to remain in their homes living independently, safely, and with dignity. Volunteers are an integral component of the Carter Burden Center’s 40+ years of success. No matter your age, experience or schedule, CBN can accommodate your needs to ensure that you have a meaningful and effective volunteer experience. The month of May is Senior Month! CBN is looking for volunteers to help us celebrate at our senior centers! Volunteers can participate in activities such as the kick off parties, art shows, ice cream socials, and Senior Celebration parties. Volunteers can choose between volunteering at the following locations: Carter Burden Luncheon Club is located at 351 East 74th Street Carter Burden/Leonard Covello Senior Program is located at 312 East 109th Street. Please join us at one or both of these locations to celebrate our wonderful seniors! Dates and times are flexible.
10021.title: Volunteer to help celebrate seniors during Senior Week!

10021.description: Make a Connection Be a Spanish Speaking Telephone Reassurance Volunteer Background: Established in 1893, Visiting Nurse Service of New York is the nation’s largest not-for-profit home based healthcare company. As a payer (Medicare Advantage, Medicaid Long Term Care) and a provider (homecare, hospice, long term care), VNSNY services more than 140,000 individuals a year in the metro New York City marketplace. Each day, over 10,000 VNSNY nurses, rehabilitation therapists, social workers, and allied professionals and paraprofessionals deliver compassionate care, unparalleled medical expertise, and 24/7 solutions. VNSNY’s charitable care and community benefit initiatives ensure that all patients receive the full range of care they need, regardless of the limits of their health care coverage. In 2016, we provided more than $16.7 million through these programs, made possible, in part, by the generous support of foundations, corporations, and individual donors. Position Description: The volunteer will make weekly phone calls to frail elderly and disabled VNSNY patients in New York City who have been identified by nurses and/or social workers as needing telephone companionship. Brief notes must be recorded on office patient log. Qualifications: Genuine desire to interact with isolated patients; good listening skills; pleasant telephone manner and voice; ability to take notes and fill out form. Attendance at one training session and familiarization with training manual required. Bilingual callers in Spanish are needed. Benefits: Satisfaction derived from interacting with patients; assisting in important patient contact to help VNSNY improve service delivered to patients; chance to work with committed professionals and volunteers; Annual Volunteer Recognition Luncheon Start Date: Flexible with minimum commitment of six months. Hours: 1.5 - 2+ hours per week to complete calls to patients from our East 70th Street headquarters. Hours are flexible 9:00 - 5:00 weekdays. Location: 107 East 70 th St., between Lexington & Park Avenues New York, NY 10021 To Apply: Interested candidates should forward cover letter and resume by e-mail to: Volguest@vnsny.org
10021.title: Brighten A Seniors Day!
10021.org: Visiting Nurse Service of New York

10021.description: Friendly Visiting is a program that pairs neighbors with homebound seniors to provide company and friendship. We ask volunteers to commit to visit their senior match one time per week for a period of six months or more.
10021.title: Friendly Visiting

10021.description: Welcome to the ASD Climber Foundation! ASD stands for Autism Spectrum Disorders. We are working with a family in your area with a child on the autism spectrum. The family wants to train volunteers to help them run a home based social skills program called the Son-Rise Program. No experience necessary. Free training provided. Time commitment is 2-4 hours a week for 6 months or more. PLEASE READ: After completing the \"I want to help\" page, you will immediately receive an auto reply email with our Volunteer Profile. Please fill this out, and we will forward it directly to the family in your area that requires help. ***please add asdclimberfoundation@me.com to your safe list and check your junk mail if you do not see an immediate response in your inbox*** Thank you for your time!
10021.title: New York, NY: Autism Volunteer (East 72nd Street)

10021.description: We are seeking early evening and overnight hosts for our homeless shelter. We are particularly interested in overnight hosts. Our shelter runs every week of the year, from Sunday-Thursday. The early evening host (6:30pm-8:30pm): Welcomes and checks-in the guests. Prepares the breakfast tray. Offers a light snack for those who missed dinner at the Drop-in Center. Makes sure that everyone has enough linens, blankets, and toiletries to be comfortable and cleans up the table and kitchen. The overnight host (8:30pm-7:00am): Organizes food clean-up with help from the guests. Makes sure breakfast is ready to go. Ensures the smooth operation of the shelter overnight, from 10:00pm lights-out to wake up, breakfast and departure in the morning. Leaves the kitchen and guest area clean and neat. Early and Overnight Hosts can volunteer by themselves or with a friend/partner/family member/etc. Our volunteers are committed to serving our shelter guests. Most hosts serve at least twice/month. Prospective hosts must attend an Open House orientation or contact us to arrange for an individual orientation. Open House Orientations are held on a monthly basis at 1:00 p.m., meeting at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church. We rely on our volunteer hosts to keep the shelter open, so we need dependable volunteers to show up for and complete every shift they agree to fill. Volunteers must be 18 or older. Volunteers must also be able to lift 20 lbs for snack set-up.
10021.title: Volunteers needed at Upper East Side Homeless Shelter

10021.description: Lenox Hill Neighborhood House, widely recognized as one of New York's premiere human services providers, is a 123-year-old settlement house that provides an extensive array of effective and integrated services which significantly improve the lives of 20,000 people in need each year, ages 3 to 103 on Manhattan's East Side. We are seeking volunteers to staff the Reception/Information desk of our vibrant, busy Senior Center two Saturdays per month from 9am-12pm. Volunteers will be responsible for checking in senior center members for meals and activities, answering in-person and phone inquiries, signing members up for trips and other light clerical tasks.
10021.title: Senior Center Receptionist

10021.description: We are seeking early evening and overnight hosts for our homeless shelter. We are particularly interested in overnight hosts. Our shelter runs every week of the year, from Sunday-Thursday. The early evening host (6:30pm-8:30pm): Welcomes and checks-in the guests. Prepares the breakfast tray. Offers a light snack for those who missed dinner at the Drop-in Center. Makes sure that everyone has enough linens, blankets, and toiletries to be comfortable and cleans up the table and kitchen. The overnight host (8:30pm-7:00am): Organizes food clean-up with help from the guests. Makes sure breakfast is ready to go. Ensures the smooth operation of the shelter overnight, from 10:00pm lights-out to wake up, breakfast and departure in the morning. Leaves the kitchen and guest area clean and neat. Early and Overnight Hosts can volunteer by themselves or with a friend/partner/family member/etc. Our volunteers are committed to serving our shelter guests. Most hosts serve at least twice/month. Prospective hosts must attend an Open House orientation or contact us to arrange for an individual orientation. Open House Orientations are held on a monthly basis at 1:00 p.m., meeting at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church. We rely on our volunteer hosts to keep the shelter open, so we need dependable volunteers to show up for and complete every shift they agree to fill. Volunteers must be 18 or older. Volunteers must also be able to lift 20 lbs for snack set-up.
10021.title: Homeless Shelter Hosts

10021.description: The Carter Burden Center for the Aging (CBCA) is dedicated to supporting the efforts of older people to remain in their homes living independently, safely, and with dignity. Volunteers are an integral component of the Carter Burden Center's 40+ years of success. No matter your age, experience or schedule, CBCA can accommodate your needs to ensure that you have a meaningful and effective volunteer experience. Everyday seniors gather to socialize and enjoy a hot meal at the Carter Burden Luncheon Club & Senior Program located in the Upper East Side and at the Carter Burden Leonard/Covello Senior Program in East Harlem. The Carter Burden Center for the Aging prides itself on serving restaurant-style meals made in our own kitchens and served on-site to our participants. Volunteers work both in the kitchen and dining room in food preparation, meal distribution, and cleaning capacities. Volunteer hours are from 10:30am to 1:00pm.
10021.title: Meal Service

10021.description: The Carter Burden Network is dedicated to supporting the efforts of older people to remain in their homes living independently, safely, and with dignity. Volunteers are an integral component of the Carter Burden Network's 40+ years of success. No matter your age, experience or schedule, CBN can accommodate your needs to ensure that you have a meaningful and effective volunteer experience. Meals-On-Wheels deliver thousands of meals a year to our homebound seniors. The Carter Burden Luncheon Club & Senior Program is looking for eager and passionate volunteers to deliver meals to our Upper East Side senior clients. It's a great opportunity to check up on the senior and converse with them. You're not just delivering a meal, but also a smile! Volunteer hours are from 10:30am to 12:30pm.
10021.title: Meal Delivery

10185.description: CALLING ALL ARTISTS! Painters, sculptors, illustrators, designers, et.al. The Arts @ Henson-Parks, Inc. is looking for artists or those who love the arts showcases their talents and crafts, while helping teach art to local youths, and those who consider themselves \"youthful\". We conduct POP-UP Art Workshops one weekend day per month in various locations around New York City and surrounding boroughs. We would promote educational and informational art-based crafts, and artist's work. You would help us organize our workshops and events. The workshops are 2-4 hours for 1 day per month, usually a Saturday. If you're an artist and want to teach a workshop - we're open to what many would consider \"transitional\" mediums, as well as experimenting with various mediums, cultural themes, and the uncommon. Our mission is educational + recreational. If you are interested in helping coordinate a POP-UP workshop , we are interested in you! Equipment and instructional tools would be provided. Own/public transporation required. Please add TheArtsAtHensonParks@Yahoo.com to your contact list so that our reply is not treated as spam. #pARTnersInART #ArtED #pARTicipate
10185.title: Art Workshops - Event Coordinators ~ help teach pop-up ART classes to youth.

10185.description: The Arts @ Henson-Parks, Inc. is currently looking for individuals well-grounded in digital photography and videography to instruct kids ages 7-18y, grades 3-12, in the basics of digital photography and editing as part of our program called \"The Pupil Project\". Weekly instruction will include educational and recreational projects that tie-in to an end-of-program showcase. Volunteering is ongoing, conducted in multi-week sessions, throughout Queens, Brooklyn, the Bronx and Manhattan. It entails a commitment of 1 days per week, 2 hours per day afterschool between the hours of 3-6pm during the school year starting Fall 2016. Equipment and instructional tools are provided. Own/public transporation required. #ThePupilProject #RedCameraCrew #pARTicipate For more information on the program visit our website: http://www.theartsathensonparks.com/programs/ .
10185.title: Photographers & Videographers -  Instruction to NYC Students after school

10036.description: Senior Medicare Patrol The Senior Medicare Patrol (SMP) is a nationwide effort to educate and empower seniors to protect themselves against fraud, learn to detect errors and report healthcare abuse. With so many scams targeting seniors, volunteers have the unique opportunity to help stop healthcare fraud at the source! The NY Senior Medicare Patrol hosts Education Sessions to teach seniors a variety of tips & tricks to ensure their healthcare benefits are safe & personal information is secure from scammers. What would a Healthcare Fraud Educator do? Senior Medicare Patrol volunteers will give education sessions to various audiences of Medicare beneficiaries, caregivers & professionals in the aging industry about Medicare & Medicaid fraud/abuse. Education sessions are hosted all throughout the NY metro area, including 5 boroughs, Westchester, & Long Island No prior healthcare education? No problem! New York Senior Medicare Patrol will provide comprehensive training to interested volunteers. Contact Victoria Thornton, Volunteer Coordinator for more information! 212-398-6565 ext 235 , vthornton@liveon-ny.org
10036.title: Healthcare Fraud Educators

10036.description: Apply your marketing skills by sharing your thoughts about our work and telling us how you think we can improve! Are you a fan of jazz and blues? Did you know that hundreds of accomplished musicians will face a serious crisis in the next year? Some 700 others will struggle to fill gaps in already meager performance schedules. Jazz and blues musicians are our heroes - so let's connect them with audiences across the country for free, fairly paying gigs! Students, seniors, general audiences... we do all kinds of shows (total 900 each year), we just need to first partner with nonprofits that can provide a space and equipment, which requires some serious promotional materials and applications for funding. That's where you come in!
10036.title: Marketing Consultant to Empower Elder Jazz Musicians

10036.description: The New York Senior Medicare Patrol (SMP) is part of a nationwide campaign to educate Medicare beneficiaries about healthcare fraud. Our mission is to reduce fraud by empowering beneficiaries to prevent, detect and report Medicare errors and abuse. We want to ensure that older adults do not have to fall victim to this abuse. SMP Volunteer Complex Interactions Specialist Volunteers who handle complex issues work individually with beneficiaries to report specific instances of suspected health care fraud, error and abuse. They help beneficiaries distinguish error from potential fraud or abuse and act on the beneficiary's behalf to correct errors and refer suspected fraud and abuse to the appropriate authorities. Volunteers who handle complex issues respond to beneficiary and caregiver inquiries that involve complaints of fraud, error, and abuse by: Interviewing the beneficiary and/or caregiver in person or by telephone Researching issues using SMP manuals and other Medicare program integrity resources Providing completed complex issues form and associated documentation of suspected fraud, error, or abuse to SMP headquarters to be reported in the SMART FACTS reporting and referrals system and for reporting to the appropriate government entity for investigation Assessing the case for further investigation and/or referral Supporting and following up with beneficiaries as their reported issue moves through the investigation and resolution process Qualifications Research and case management skills Ability and willingness to learn and share information related to preventing, detecting, and reporting health care billing mistakes, fraud, and abuse Ability to follow case referral protocols Ability to work independently Computer literacy, including ability to use the Internet and on line reporting programs Time Commitment: Volunteer schedules are flexible. The Volunteer Coordinator works with each volunteer to determine the number of hours the volunteer works each month, and to schedule assignments accordingly. Because of the training SMP volunteers receive, they are asked to commit to a minimum of one year. Training/Support: All New York SMP volunteers receive training on the SMP program, Medicare Basics, and Medicare Fraud and Abuse. Volunteers will also be invited to attend update trainings made available by the New York SMP program or other program partner agencies.
10036.title: Fraud/Abuse Specialist

10036.description: Senior Medicare Patrol The Senior Medicare Patrol (SMP) is a nationwide effort to educate and empower seniors to protect themselves against fraud, learn to detect errors and report healthcare abuse. With so many scams targeting seniors, volunteers have the unique opportunity to help stop healthcare fraud at the source! The NY Senior Medicare Patrol hosts Education Sessions to teach seniors a variety of tips & tricks to ensure their healthcare benefits are safe & personal information is secure from scammers. In effort to reach out to limited/non-English speaking communities, the Senior Medicare Patrol needs bilingual speakers to assist us with translation services. Languages needed include: Spanish, Chinese (Mandarin & Cantonese), Russian & Korean What would a Senior Medicare Patrol volunteer do? Senior Medicare Patrol volunteers will translate education sessions to various audiences of Medicare beneficiaries, caregivers & professionals in the aging industry about Medicare & Medicaid fraud/abuse. Education sessions are hosted all throughout the NY metro area, including all 5 boroughs, Westchester, & Long Island No prior healthcare education? No problem! New York Senior Medicare Patrol will provide comprehensive training to interested volunteers.
10036.title: Senior Medicare Patrol Bilingual Speakers!

10036.description: Come join us as we educate children about healthy eating, food and taste. What do Volunteers do? Volunteers are an essential component of the work that we do with children, helping out in the classroom but also providing a mentoring role for children. After participating in a hands on training, volunteers are partnered with a Spoons Across America Educator and assist in all aspects of program implementation. We look for an ongoing commitment between volunteers and a particular classroom or school, yet can also accommodate one-time volunteers. Volunteer responsibilities include assisting with program set up, working directly with children, teaching cooking skills, and assisting in the kitchen where appropriate. We are looking for individuals enthusiastic about healthy eating and children’s programming to join us! When and where are your programs? We teach programs for school children across the NYC boroughs. Programs occur throughout the school year and there are opportunities for an extended commitment as well as one-time opportunities. Will I be trained? All volunteers receive training at the Spoons Across America offices (630 Ninth Ave @ 44 th St in Manhattan), and are required to attend one of the following training dates: Wednesday March 1st: 5:00-6:30 Monday, March 6th: 12:00-1:30 What programs do you have? We have a number of on-going programs for school age children in New York City. See attached for program descriptions and our website www.spoonsacrossamerica.org. I'm ready to go! How do I sign up? If you are interested in volunteering with Spoons Across America this year. Please contact Ali McDowell, Director of Programs and Partnerships, at ali@spoonsacrossamerica.org. In your email, please indicate the following: - Training session you will attend: Wedndesday, March 1st: 5:00-6:30 or Monday, November6 th: 12:00-1:30 - Programs you are interested in. * Please note: Volunteers must complete a background check prior to the program date I want to volunteer, but I am not available right now. Will there be other opportunities to get involved? Definitely! If you are unable to volunteer at this point, we will have other opportunities available this winter and spring. If possible, please attend one of the trainings in November. Programs are ongoing and once you are trained you will be able to volunteer. Additional trainings will be held later this year. I want to volunteer, but I can’t attend the training.Will there be other trainings? Depending upon need and availability, additional trainings may be scheduled this fall. Please contact Ali with your availability. * Do you work for a business or company that wants to make a volunteer commitment? We can schedule a special training sessions for groups of 10 or more people, onsite or at our offices. Contact Ali for more information.
10036.title: Volunteer as a Food Educators in NYC Elementary Classrooms- New Trainings in March
10036.org: From Farm to Table d/b/a Spoons Across America

10036.description: The New York Senior Medicare Patrol (SMP) project is part of a nationwide campaign to educate Medicare beneficiaries about the consequences and direct impact of healthcare fraud. Last year we lost an estiimated $65 billion to Medicare fraud and abuse! Our mission is to empower and educate beneficiaries to prevent,. detect and report Medicare fraud. We work to ensure that older adults do not have to fall victim to this abuse. SMP Volunteer Complex Interactions Specialist Volunteers who handle complex issues work individually with beneficiaries to report specific instances of suspected health care fraud, error and abuse. They help beneficiaries distinguish error from potential fraud or abuse and act on the beneficiary's behalf to correct errors and refer suspected fraud and abuse to the appropriate authorities. Volunteers who handle complex issues respond to beneficiary and caregiver inquiries that involve complaints of fraud, error, and abuse by: Interviewing the beneficiary and/or caregiver in person or by telephone Researching issues using SMP manuals and other Medicare program integrity resources Providing completed complex issues form and associated documentation of suspected fraud, error, or abuse to SMP headquarters to be reported in the SMART FACTS reporting and referrals system and for reporting to the appropriate government entity for investigation Assessing the case for further investigation and/or referral Supporting and following up with beneficiaries as their reported issue moves through the investigation and resolution process Qualifications Research and case management skills Ability and willingness to learn and share information related to preventing, detecting, and reporting health care billing mistakes, fraud, and abuse Ability to follow case referral protocols Ability to work independently Computer literacy, including ability to use the Internet and on line reporting programs Time Commitment: Volunteer schedules are flexible. The Volunteer Coordinator works with each volunteer to determine the number of hours the volunteer works each month, and to schedule assignments accordingly. Because of the training SMP volunteers receive, they are asked to commit to a minimum of one year. Training/Support: All New York SMP volunteers receive training on the SMP program, Medicare Basics, and Medicare Fraud and Abuse. Volunteers will also be invited to attend update trainings made available by the New York SMP program or other program partner agencies.
10036.title: SMP Fraud/Abuse Specialist

10036.description: BUILD is an innovative, college preparatory program. We use entrepreneurship to ignite the potential of youth from under-resourced communities and propel them to high school, college & career success. Volunteer as a BUILD mentor! BUILD Mentors are placed with a high school student team, coaching them through the process of launching real businesses. This makes school more relevant and fun! Mentors can come from any professional background - sharing your skill-sets with students inspires them to stay on the path to college success. Interested in getting involved but can’t mentor weekly? BUILD has one-off and group volunteer opportunities as well. Please email Miranda Bellizia for additional information. Here are some details on what a mentoring commitment looks like: Location: Manhattan, Brooklyn or the Bronx Time commitment: 1 hour, once a week (M-Th) (Group and Virtual options available) Session runs: September 2016 - June 2017 (with winter and spring breaks) 1 mentors assigned per team (1:4 mentor to student ratio) Sites are accessible through public transportation Get started! Fill out our online application here: www.build.org/volunteer Got questions? Email us aNYCVolunteers@build.org
10036.title: Empower Youth Entrepreneurs. Be a BUILD Mentor!

10036.description: If you experienced a mental health challenge in college, you have an intimate understanding of the difficulties our students are going through. As a mentor, you can help make this process easier for our students by being the confidant and friend that can relate to them in a way that no one else can. Being a mentor can be very rewarding. It allows you to draw on your experience, share what you have learned, and turn what might have been a great challenge in your life into something positive. Check us out and download the application at collegereentry.org
10036.title: Help a college student struggling with mental health.  Become a Mentor!

10036.description: Lar Lubovitch and the Board of Directors are pleased to invite you to join the newly formed Junior Board of the Lar Lubovitch Dance Company. Membership on the Junior Board offers a unique opportunity to personally participate in the organization of this prestigious New York dance company. A short list of the benefits includes the following: -Invitations to special junior board member events throughout the year. -Attendance at private rehearsals with dancers and choreographer. -Access to a backstage experience and a chance to meet the dancers. -Acknowledgement and listed by name in all printed programs. -Priority seating for friends purchasing Gala tickets. -Involvement in the planning and staging of dance events To join the Junior Board, each member undertakes the responsibility of a $250 membership per year plus the commitment of selling 5 Gala tickets to the company’s principal event of the season.
10036.title: Seeking Junior Board Members

10036.description: UX is a development institution that is forward thinking, free of cost, and open to people of all ages. It is a new crossroads for learning. The whole city is its campus. It takes place at the All Stars Project headquarters on 42nd St. and it also takes place in corporate boadrooms and back stage at Broadway theatres, in your neighborhood and at your school, even in your living room if you want it to. It has no tuition and no grades. We are looking for mature adults of all ages, open-minded thinkers, self-starters with organization and planning skills. Good oral and written communication skills. Administrative skills; including but not limited to: Microsoft Suite & Database management. Willingness to travel throughout N.Y.C.'s five boroughs. Some evening and weekend availability a plus.
10036.title: UX - Volunteer

10036.description: Work with our dynamic Sales and Marketing Director to promote a variety of All Stars productions -- from Hip-Hop Cabarets to avante garde drama to community open houses. Work includes targeting various constituencies through online media and phone outreach. Creative ideas and campaigns are welcomed. Day time hours are best.
10036.title: Volunteer Theatre Sales Support

10036.description: The Lar Lubovitch Dance Company is world-renowned. We currently have 14 dedicated members on our Senior Board, and we are now seeking to add 3 or 4 more lovers of dance to our circle of supporters. Prospective board members should have an appreciation of dance and be willing to work with other like-minded professionals, helping the company realize its mission. The commitment of time and money are both very reasonable -- while the emotional and spiritual rewards are enormous. We would be very happy to meet with you and let you see what we are all about. Please contact us at your earliest convenience.
10036.title: Seeking Senior Board Members

10036.description: Looking for caring adults to volunteer to support an innovative performance and development program that involves more than 10,000 young people in New York City each year. In the \"All Stars Talent Show,\" every young person who auditions makes it into the show. Adult and youth volunteers work together to conduct community outreach and help produce auditions, workshops and shows. Our \"Center for Youth Development\" on West 42nd Street is the producing headquarters for these off-site productions, which take place in inner-city communities throughout New York City.
10036.title: Inner-City Youth Talent Show Support Staff

10036.description: Castillo Theatre Production Volunteer - A showplace for the plays of Fred Newman and Heiner Muller, a multicultural home for Black theatre, and a hotbed of theatrical improvisation, Castillo includes people of all ages and backgrounds in its creative life. Embarking on its 32nd season, The award winning Castillo Theater brings socially relevant theatre, dealing with contemporary and historical social issues to the heart of New York's commercial theatre district. Volunteers are needed to support all aspects of the theatre. marketing and sales,set design, costumes, wardrobe, lighting, sound, stage management, box office, house staff,theatre administration, audience development, and much more! Most positions will train. Schedules are varied and flexible; however, for some technical positions in the theatre a stable, reliable schedule is essential. Some evening and weekend availability needed.
10036.title: Castillo Theater Production Volunteer

10116.description: Hello everyone, We are a small literacy nonprofit organization that is looking for volunteers with a passion for fundraising, marketing/outreach and social media! Specifically we are hoping people with technical, marketing or business skills to join our board but it's not a must. Please feel free to contact us even if you don't have the skills. Please if you are interested in joining our team & getting books to kids who need them the most, call 347.856.8357 or send an email christina@readinghamlets.org. Thank you www.readinghamlets.org
10116.title: Fundraiser position

10116.description: Volunteer Board Member Young Starr Movement, INC. Greater New York City Area Nonprofit Organization Job Description Seeking Member of the Board of Directors Mission Young Starr Movement, INC. Nonprofit’s mission is to improve the lives of people affected by domestic violence abuse. The Young Starr Movement, fights for more than 38 million women who have experienced either physical domestic abuse, financial abuse, emotional abuse or a combination of all three. There can be and should be a life after a physical or emotional crisis for more people. Our mission is to educate, empower, support and give necessary resources to rebuild and change lives. The Young Starr Movement provides direct services and life skills training to anyone affected by domestic violence abuse; and community crisis intervention. Our innovative programs and life skills training are aimed at reversing the negative effects of silence and violence affecting thousands of people in our communities. We are commited to the recovery of women and people of all background and ages through empowerment, stability, and self-fullfilment. For more information, please visit our website at www.youngstarrmovement.org. Position The Board will support the work of Young Starr Movement, INC. and provide mission-based leadership and strategic governance. While day-to-day operations are led by Young Starr Movement, Founder and President, the Board-President relationship is a partnership, and the appropriate involvement of the Board is both critical and expected. Specific Board Member responsibilities include: Leadership, governance and oversight Serving as a trusted advisor to the President as she develops and implements Young Starr Movement, strategic plan. Reviewing outcomes and metrics created by Young Starr Movement, for evaluating its impact, and regularly measuring its performance and effectiveness using those metrics; reviewing agenda and supporting materials prior to board and committee meetings. Approving Young Starr Movement's annual budget, audit reports, and material business decisions; being informed of, and meeting all, legal and fiduciary responsibilities. Contributing to an annual performance evaluation of the President. Assisting the President and board chair in identifying and recruiting other Board Members. Partnering with the President and other board members to ensure that board resolutions are carried out. Serving on committees or task forces and taking on special assignments. Representing Young Starr Movement to stakeholders; acting as an ambassador for the organization. Ensuring Young Starr Movement’s commitment to a diverse board and staff that reflects the communities Young Starr Movement serves. Fundraising Young Starr Movement Board Members will consider Young Starr Movement a philanthropic priority and make annual gifts that reflect that priority so that Young Starr Movement can credibly solicit contributions from foundations, organizations, and individuals, Young Starr Movement, INC. expects to have 100 percent of Board Members make an annual contribution that is commensurate with their capacity. Board Terms/Participation Young Starr Movement’s Board Members will serve a three-year term to be eligible for re-appointment for one additional term. Board meetings will be held quarterly and committee meetings will be held in coordination with full board meetings. Qualifications This is an extraordinary opportunity for an individual who is passionate about Young Starr Movement’s mission and who has a track record of board leadership. Selected Board Members will have achieved leadership stature in business, government, philanthropy, or the nonprofit sector. His/her accomplishments will allow him/her to attract other well-qualified, high-performing Board Members. Ideal candidates will have the following qualifications: Extensive professional experience with significant executive leadership accomplishments in business, government, philanthropy, or the nonprofit sector. A commitment to and understanding of Young Starr Movement’s beneficiaries, preferably based on experience. Savvy diplomatic skills and a natural affinity for cultivating relationships and persuading, convening, facilitating, and building consensus among diverse individuals. Personal qualities of integrity, credibility, and a passion for improving the lives of Young Starr Movement’s beneficiaries. Service on Young Starr Movement’s Board of Directors is without remuneration, except for administrative support, travel, and accommodation costs in relation to Board Members’ duties.
10116.title: Volunteer Board Member

This is a summer camp for the children MDA serves living with muscular dystrophy and other muscle diseases. MDA camp features sports, swimming, campfires, dances, and more! Each camper is paired with their own counselor for the week. Camp is not only a place to have fun, but it is also a place of understanding, confidence, and hope. When asked their favorite holiday, our kids respond with summer camp! Camp provides excellent practical experience for individuals in medical school, physical and occupational therapy programs, and nursing programs. However, no prior experience is required to be a part of this amazing opportunity. We are currently looking for volunteers to make camp possible for Summer 2017. You must be 16 years or older to apply. You must be able to lift at least 50 lbs. MDA Summer Camps for the NY/NJ area are held during the first three weeks of August 2017 (specific dates to be announced next month). Interested or know someone who would be? 10017.description: We are currently recruiting new co-organizers for the NYC chapter of the Action Corps. This is a rewarding volunteer position that allows the individuals to cultivate their leadership skills and creativity, all while fighting global poverty and hunger. Action Corps NYC is a national, volunteer-led, grassroots effort to fight poverty, hunger, and injustice around the world. We make it our mission to educate the community on global campaigns and initiatives that many times are life changing to those with a voice. We have worked on the Green Climate Fund, the refugee crisis, American poultry works, women cocoa farmers, food aid reform, and many many others. We table at local events and concerts, plan our own events, and send communications and requests to legislators and corporations insisting upon better practices and reform. We’re not a stiff group; we try to have fun, but still take our work and efforts very seriously. As a co-organizer, you would lead the monthly meetings, maintain the email accounts, tell people what to do J, and just help keep us on track. We have core volunteers who will be there every step of the way, including our current organizers who have been leading for 2.5 years. But it’s important to turn over leadership to ensure that vitality, creativity, and vision remains strong. Most of the responsibilities would be remote, but you do need to attend events within the city at least monthly. Please email us for more information or complete the application here. https://goo.gl/forms/xVPKO6ztn3jS43hF2
10017.title: Volunteer Co-Organizer of Action Corps NYC

10017.description: Help New Yorkers understand their health insurance and access the health care they need. Our volunteers assist New Yorkers whether on Medicaid, Medicare, private insurance, or uninsured. By staffing our toll-free statewide helpline, volunteers provide direct one-on-one assistance to individuals and families and make a difference in people’s lives. The Community Service Society’s Community Health Advocates (\"CHA\") program, New York’s designated health insurance consumer assistance program, helps New Yorkers use and keep their health insurance and access affordable health care. The CHA helpline is open from 9a.m. to 4p.m., Monday through Friday. We are looking for volunteers who are able to work one full day or two 4-hour shifts, for a minimum 6 month commitment. Our next open houses for interested volunteers will take place on May 17. Please contact alofters@cssny.org for more information. Our next intensive training for our new volunteer class will take place in early June. Volunteer responsibilities include : Answering the Community Health Advocates helpline phone calls. Conducting intake to gather necessary information from Helpline callers. Providing information, advice, referrals, and informal advocacy services to Helpline callers about their health insurance benefits and health care rights. Working closely with CHA staff to inform Helpline callers about how their health insurance works and how to access affordable health care services. Database entry that includes detailed notes. Carefully follow client privacy protection guidelines. Preferred Skills and Interests: Willing to learn a broad array of health law, health policy, and health advocacy. Interest in serving low-income populations. Strong customer service skills including both listening and speaking skills (Competency in languages other than English a plus). Proficient in data entry and Microsoft word. Clear writing skills. Comfortable working independently with supervision as needed. Strong research skills and comfortable with online research. Available for an intensive training program and ongoing mini-trainings. Able to commit to volunteering approximately 8 hours a week for 6 months.
10017.title: Community Health Advocates Helpline Volunteer

10017.description: Want to make a difference? Started in 1966 by the Community Service Society, an over 170-year-old nonprofit agency, RSVP matches the skills and interests of adults 55 and older with volunteer opportunities at New York City nonprofits. With more than 2,300 volunteers, RSVP in New York City is one of the largest senior volunteer programs in the nation. There are over 600 RSVPs which operate nationally and many that do so internationally. Become a member of RSVP in New York City! Most RSVP volunteers have assignments in one or more of our focus areas: education, healthy futures, economic opportunity, veterans and military families, environmental stewardship, and disaster services. Their activities include, but are not limited to, mentoring troubled children; providing homework assistance at libraries; tutoring children in schools and after-school programs; teaching adult education, GED prep, or English as a second language; helping to deliver meals to older adults; providing financial coaching and benefits counseling; assisting at soup kitchens and food pantries; and so much more! If you are 55 or older and would like to attend one of our upcoming Open Houses or otherwise learn more about us and how we can help you find a meaningful volunteer opportunity, reach out today!
10017.title: Many Volunteer Opportunities Available for Adults 55 and Older

10065.description: The City Tutors is seeking an individual who will support the communications unit of The City Tutors. Note: Much of the work can be done virtually with some visits to campus. Goals: promote The City Tutors brand, allowing us to reach more prospective tutors and partners profile current and past City Tutors to help build stronger ties between tutors develop original content that grows our social media audience educate on and promote issues that we are tackling through our programs We are seeking someone who is in NYC to Write stories about CT that will be featured on our Facebook and website Create a newsletter covering events from summer and the fall semester Interview tutors for a \"Spotlight on a Tutor\" series Collaborate with our nascent Hunter chapter as they develop coherent marketing strategies Promote our partnerships with different educational sites Update website, and run our Twitter feed
10065.title: Marketing/Communications Intern

10065.description: The City Tutors (CT) is working with College Now to support students in their Saturday Human Biology course. We are currently looking for two embedded tutors to support two sections of this course. This is a great opportunity for a student studying science education or interested in tutoring science. In this role, you would work collaboratively with an instructor to improve students’ performance, while being supported and guided by an experienced academic support professional. As a tutor for the biology course in College Now, you would commit to three hours on Saturday, broken down as the last two hours of the 9-1:20PM course with the possibility of an extra hour after class. You would identify and support students who are struggling, participate during the lecture to support the class on the whole, and provide feedback to the instructor regarding students' concerns and difficulties that can lead to changes in future lessons. You might also design assignments, identify/track students who are struggling and create for them differentiated instruction. CT's embedded tutoring program has been successful in helping students gain access to support that they otherwise could not receive given their limited availability to be on campus Saturdays. Having a tutor in the class early in the semester will allow us to push to reduce withdrawals and student failure rates. Your work would not only help the class, but help us improve this model so that we can expand it across all the courses within College Now, and across departments where appropriate as well. To apply, you must: have received an A- or A in introduction to biology have a GPA at or above 3.2, or have completed a degree in biology/other natural sciences submit biweekly reports, and meet through Google Hangout/in person with the director on a biweekly basis. be willing to complete 10 hours of College Reading and Learning Aligned (CRLA) training. Training days will be determined based on your schedule and that of the Tutor Training Coordinators.
10065.title: Saturday Biology Classroom Tutor for College Now

10065.description: Every year, hundreds of students visit the MVHMG to learn about the history of New York City. Volunteer educators facilitate our classes that are developmentally appropriate for each age group and allow children to learn about social history during the 1820s and 30s, a time of important changes and growth for the city. Topics include immigration, urbanization, industrialization, diversity, and changing technology. While we provide training, we ask that educators have previous experience working with children. MVHMG volunteers need to be dependable, flexible, and have a sense of humor. They should be able to stand for periods of time and be able to walk up stairs. After training, volunteers need to teach at least three days a month for at least a year. Volunteers need email and internet access. Benefits: Training in interactive, informal teaching skills; complimentary admission to many NYC museums via Museum ID card; museum shop discount; and the opportunity to work with people interested in historic sites, teaching, and children's learning. The Mount Vernon Hotel Museum & Garden (MVHMG) preserves and interprets travel, leisure, work and play in diverse antebellum New York. The Museum shares and promotes historical knowledge for the education and enjoyment of the public through engaging interpretation and programs. The Museum presents its 1799 building and grounds as the Mount Vernon Hotel, which served day customers and travelers from 1826 to 1833.
10065.title: Volunteer Educator

10065.description: CT is partnered with Manhattan International High School (located at 317 East 67 th Street), which serves students who have been in the country for five or less years. CT provides volunteer Reading and Writing tutors (who are trained during the course of their tutoring) to support students in their preparation for the Regents Exam, the statewide high school exit examination. Reading and Writing tutoring takes place at the high school on Thursdays 3PM-4PM. If you are interested in becoming a reading/writing tutor, please send thenycitytutors@gmail.com your unofficial (online) transcript from all colleges and/or universities you have attended, along with your resume. If you have any questions or concerns please feel free to email thenycitytutors@gmail.com. You can visit CT’s website www.thecitytutors.com for more information.
10065.title: Reading/Writing Tutor Needed

10065.description: The City Tutors (thecitytutors.com) seeks individuals to fill key administrative positions across the organization. We are currently seeking: Professional Case Managers (should be interested or have a background in social work/professional development) Marketing Agents (outgoing and proactive!) Online Content Managers (aggregating and presenting artifacts of our work and articles/policy issues/trends relevant to our work) Original Online Content Creators (including investigative and editorial writers) Videographer (need to know Final Cut Pro, and own your own camera) Tutor Trainers Supplemental Instruction Supervisors
10065.title: Administrative position available. We will tailor to your interests and goals!

10065.description: Tutor a subject of your choosing for City College's College Now, a CUNY wide program that provides high school students the opportunity to take college classes for college credit; Black Male Initiative RAPSI (Retention, Achievement, Professionalism Success Institute), which mentors and provides tutoring for minority students at risk of dropping out; Manhattan International High School, which serves students who have been in the country for five or less years; or Pre-Law Program and Economics/Business Department at City College.
10065.title: Become a tutor for a subject of your choosing

10080.description: This opportunity is available every Saturday & Sunday! Help get excess bagels donated from a really great food business! The final destination will be the NYC Rescue Mission at 90 Lafayette Street. Middleweight: the average amount of food is 15-20 pounds. Sign up directly on our calendar: http://www.rescuingleftovercuisine.org/calendar

10030.description: Behind the Book works directly in New York City public schools, providing rich, innovative literacy programs to urban classrooms. Working with students from pre-K to 12th grade, Behind the Book identifies books that speak to students, then partners with teachers to create immersive curriculum units that bring the authors into classrooms. Through a series of workshops, authors discuss their book and teach a genre of writing, encouraging students to see themselves as readers and writers. Behind the Book seeks a Program Intern to assist with the design, implementation, and administration of our school programs. The intern will work closely with the Director of Programming and the Program Coordinators to support all aspects of our programs. The position is based in our Harlem office. The commitment is for one semester, minimum two days per week, hours are flexible. Responsibilities include: Working with students in classrooms Managing the Behind the Book library; conducting research and managing review copies Assisting with student book publication as needed Supporting staff with program logistics and administration Assisting in creating lesson plans, activities and worksheets for our school programs QUALIFICATIONS: Detail-oriented, eager to learn, and able to manage tasks independently. Excellent written and oral communication skills in English are required, as are strong skills in Microsoft Office. A background in education theory or previous teaching experience a plus. TO APPLY: Please submit a resume, cover letter, and a one-page writing sample to Jo Umans at info@BehindtheBook.org. \"Program Intern\" should appear in the subject heading of your email. Deadlines to apply for next two semesters: Spring 2017: February 13th Summer 2017: May 31st Behind the Book is committed to providing equal opportunity to all employees and applicants without regard to race, color, religion, national origin, sex, age, marital status, sexual orientation, disability, political affiliation, family responsibilities, or any other characteristic protected under federal, state, or local law. We are committed to maximizing the diversity of our organization, as we want to engage all those who can contribute to this effort.
10030.title: Program Intern

Through a series of workshops, authors discuss their book and teach a genre of writing, encouraging students to see themselves as readers and writers. Learn more about Behind the Book on our website. Behind the Book seeks a Fundraising and Development Intern to assist the Development Manager in all aspects of fundraising. The position will be based at our Harlem office. Responsibilities include: Researching prospective funders Assisting with donor communication, including thank you letters, appeal letters, and letters of inquiry to foundations Publicizing donations (and/or profiling donors) on Behind the Book’s website, newsletter and social media Assisting with database management (training on Salesforce provided) Assisting with promoting fundraising events. We are committed to maximizing the diversity of our organization, as we want to engage all those who can contribute to this effort.
10030.title: Fundraising & Development Intern
